member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.FallbackFontCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection of fonts where a substitution for glyphs is searched in the first place.

remarks.para: If there is no the glyph in the required font, then Graphics Mill looks for the substitution in this collection first. If the glyph still not found, then the first applicable glyph in is used.

member.summary: Gets or sets the bold style emulation of the font.
member.value: true if bold style emulation is enabled; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: Most font families have regular, bold, and italic styles. However, what if you need to draw a bold and/or italic text, but a font family does not contain the corresponding styles? In this case you can use the and properties for emulating bold and italic styles.

member.summary: Gets or sets the hinting of the font. Hinting is the adjustment of glyphs for lining them up with rasterized pixels.

remarks.para: This mechanism allows for displaying vector text without visible distortion even at low resolution screens.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.FontMetrics
member.summary: Represents font characteristics for a font at a given text size.

remarks.para: All metrics are measured in pixels.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.FontMetrics.Ascender
member.summary: Gets the vertical distance from the horizontal baseline to the highest character coordinate in a font face, in pixels.
member.value: The vertical distance from the horizontal baseline to the highest character coordinate in a font face, in pixels.

remarks.para: Unfortunately, font formats do not define the ascender in a uniform way. For some formats, it represents the ascent of all capital latin characters (without accents), for others it is the ascent of the highest accented character, and finally, other formats define it as being equal to the maximum y coordinate of the black box.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.FontMetrics.Descender
member.summary: Gets the vertical distance from the horizontal baseline to the lowest character coordinate in a font face, in pixels.
member.value: The vertical distance from the horizontal baseline to the lowest character coordinate in a font face, in pixels.

remarks.para: Unfortunately, font formats don't define the descender in a uniform way. For some formats, it represents the descent of all capital latin characters (without accents), for others it is the ascent of the lowest accented character, and finally, other formats define it as being equal to the minimum y coordinate of the black box. This field is negative for values below the baseline.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.FontMetrics.Height
member.summary: Gets the default line spacing (the baseline-to-baseline distance), in pixels, when writing text with this font.
member.value: The default line spacing (the baseline-to-baseline distance), in pixels, when writing text with this font.

remarks.para: This value usually is larger than the sum of the ascender and descender taken as absolute values. There is also no guarantee that no glyphs extend above or below subsequent baselines when using this distance. You may think of it as a value the designer of the font finds appropriate.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.FontMetrics.UnderlinePosition
member.summary: Gets the vertical position of the underline bar's center, relative to the baseline, in pixels.
member.value: The vertical position of the underline bar's center, relative to the baseline, in pixels.

remarks.para: It is negative if it is below the baseline.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.FontMetrics.UnderlineThickness
member.summary: Gets the vertical thickness of the underline.
member.value: The vertical thickness of the underline.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.Graphics
member.summary: Represents the advanced drawing functionality provided by Graphics Mill.

remarks.para: This class is implemented with Anti-Grain Geometry (AGG), that allows getting high quality and precise drawings. The class provides number of methods to draw outlined (DrawFoo methods) and filled (FillFoo methods) lines, curves, shapes, and paths.
With the set of methods you can combine and overlay images.
Also this class provides a canvas for text output. You can create plain, bounded, distorted, and art texts on .

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.Graphics.DrawBezier(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.Pen,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Draws a Bezier spline defined by four ordered pairs of coordinates that represent points.

overloads.summary: Draws a Bezier spline.

member.param: A that determines the color, width, and style of the curve.
The x-coordinate of the starting point of the curve.
The y-coordinate of the starting point of the curve.
The x-coordinate of the first control point for the curve.
The y-coordinate of the first control point for the curve.
The x-coordinate of the second control point for the curve.
The y-coordinate of the second control point for the curve.
The x-coordinate of the ending point of the curve.
The y-coordinate of the ending point of the curve.

remarks.para: A Bezier spline is defined with four points: first and last point specify beginning and end of the curve, second and third points specify so-called control points. The control points act as magnets, pulling the curve in certain directions to influence the way the Bezier spline bends.

remarks.para: A Bezier spline is defined with four points: first and last point specify beginning and end of the curve, second and third points specify so-called control points. The control points act as magnets, pulling the curve in certain directions to influence the way the Bezier spline bends.

member.param: A that determines the color, width, and style of the curve.
An array of structures that represents the curves.

remarks.para: A Bezier spline is defined with four points: first and last point specify beginning and end of the curve, second and third points specify so-called control points. The control points act as magnets, pulling the curve in certain directions to influence the way the Bezier spline bends.
The ending point of one spline will be the starting point of the next one. Therefore, for splines, except for the first one in the array, you need to specify three points instead of four.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.Graphics.DrawImage(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap,System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Draws the specified at the specified location and with the specified size.

overloads.summary: Draws the specified image on the .

member.param: The to draw.
A structure that specifies the location and size of the drawn image. The image is scaled to fit the rectangle.

remarks.para: The is drawn to destination rectangle on this . If the current image dimensions differ from dimensions of the destination rectangle, the image will be resized to have the same size as the destination rectangle.
If you want this method to calculate width and/or height automatically, you can pass 0s as the dstRect rectangle dimensions. The image dimensions will be calculated with the following way:

item.description: If both width and heigth are 0, the source image dimensions ( and ) will be taken. This way the image will not be resized during drawing.

If only one of arguments is 0, this argument will be calculated as to save image proportion. For example, the source image is 800x600, and you pass 400 as width and 0 as height. Height will be calculated to preserve aspect ratio of the image, i.e. it will be 300.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.StringMeasure.Descender
member.summary: Gets or sets string descender.
member.value: The string descender.

remarks.para: String descender is the vertical distance from the horizontal baseline to the lowest character coordinate in a string, in pixels.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.AdvancedDrawing.StringMeasure.Height
member.summary: Gets or sets string height.
member.value: The string height.

remarks.para: String height is the default line spacing (the baseline-to-baseline distance) in pixels. This value usually is larger than the sum of the ascender and descender taken as absolute values. There is also no guarantee that no glyphs extend above or below subsequent baselines when using this distance. You may think of it as a value the designer of the font finds appropriate.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap
member.summary: Represents a bitmap, i.e. an object which stores raster data.

remarks.para: This class incapsulates a raster image and stores a bitmap as well as other related data.
Using appropriate properties you can get such details about loaded image as , , , etc.

To apply some effect or transform, you should pass this bitmap into the method of an appropriate class descendant. Alternatively, you can use the property which returns the . It is less flexible, but has shorter syntax.

If you need to work with bitmap channels: split channels into several grayscale bitmaps, replace some channel with a grayscale image, swap channels, add/remove an alpha channel, etc. In this case you can use the property which returns the .
If you need to get/set the single pixel value, you can use easy-to-use pair of methods /.
To save the result to file you can either use format writers or the method.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.ApplyTransform(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.IBitmapTransform)
member.summary: Applies the specified transfrom to this bitmap.
member.param: A to apply.

member.summary: Gets an object which provides access to various operations with bitmap channels.
member.value: A object containing methods which allow operating with bitmap channels.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.ColorAdjustment
member.summary: Gets an object providing methods which are responsible for color adjustment and tone correction (brightness/contrast, levels, hue/saturation/lightness adjustment, etc.).
member.value: A class instance providing methods which are responsible for color adjustment and tone correction.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.ColorManagement
member.summary: Gets an object providing methods which are responsible for color management.
member.value: A class instance providing methods which are responsible for color management.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.ColorProfile
member.summary: Gets or sets a color profile associated with this bitmap.
member.value: A associated with this bitmap.
member.remarks: If no color profile was loaded from a file (e.g. file has no embedded profile) this property returns null.

example.para: ColorProfile property can be also used to embed another profile into the image:

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.DrawOn(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Int32,System.Int32,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode)
member.summary: Draws the current bitmap on a given System.Drawing.Graphics object (standard .NET class for drawing).
member.param: A System.Drawing.Graphics object on which the current bitmap should be drawn.
The x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the drawn image.
The y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the drawn image.
The images blending algorithm (plain pixels copying, alpha blending, bitwise operations, etc).

remarks.para: The bitmap is drawn to the destination rectangle on the given System.Drawing.Graphics object with dimensions equal to the dimensions of the bitmap.
remarks.note: If the bitmap has pixel format which is not GDI-compatible (e.g. extended pixel formats, CMYK, etc) method will automatically create a copy converted to the . That's why you always get it drawn, but if you are going to call this method multiple times, it is recommended to convert the bitmap to some GDI-compatible format (like ) to increase the performance.

overloads.summary: Draws a bitmap on various surfaces as or classes, or Windows GDI device context.

The images blending algorithm (plain pixels copying, alpha blending, bitwise operations, etc).
The opacity of the image in range [0, 1]. If 0, image is completely transparent, if 1, image is completely opaque.
The resize algorithm. Using this parameter you can select between speed and quality of resizing.

remarks.para: The bitmap is drawn to the destination rectangle on the given System.Drawing.Graphics object with dimensions equal to the dimensions of the bitmap.
remarks.note: If the bitmap has pixel format which is not GDI-compatible (e.g. extended pixel formats, CMYK, etc) method will automatically create a copy converted to the . That's why you always get it drawn, but if you are going to call this method multiple times, it is recommended to convert the bitmap to some GDI-compatible format (like ) to increase the performance.
remarks.para: If you want this method to calculate width and height automatically, you can pass 0 to the corresponding arguments. The dimensions will be calculated with the following way:

item.description: If both width and heigth are 0, it will take source image dimensions ( and properties). This way the image will not be resized during drawing.

If only one of arguments is 0, it will calculate this argument to save proportion. For example, the source image is 800x600, and you pass 400 as width and 0 as height. Height will be calculated to preserve aspect ratio of the image, i.e. it will be 300.

If only one of arguments is 0, it will calculate this argument to save proportion. For example, the source image is 800x600, and you pass 400 as width and 0 as height. Height will be calculated to preserve aspect ratio of the image, i.e. it will be 300.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.DrawOn(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.Drawing.Rectangle,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode,System.Single,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ResizeInterpolationMode)
member.summary: Draws the current bitmap on a given System.Drawing.Graphics object (standard .NET class for drawing).
member.param: A System.Drawing.Graphics object on which the current bitmap should be drawn.
structure that specifies the location and size of the drawn image.
structure that specifies the portion of the image object to draw.
The images blending algorithm (plain pixels copying, alpha blending, bitwise operations, etc).
The opacity of the image in range [0, 1]. If 0, image is completely transparent, if 1, image is completely opaque.
The resize algorithm. Using this parameter you can select between speed and quality of resizing.

remarks.para: The bitmap is drawn to the destination rectangle on the given System.Drawing.Graphics object with dimensions equal to the dimensions of the bitmap.
remarks.note: If the bitmap has pixel format which is not GDI-compatible (e.g. extended pixel formats, CMYK, etc) method will automatically create a copy converted to the . That's why you always get it drawn, but if you are going to call this method multiple times, it is recommended to convert the bitmap to some GDI-compatible format (like ) to increase the performance.
remarks.para: If you want this method to calculate width and height automatically, you can pass 0 to the corresponding arguments. The dimensions will be calculated with the following way:

If only one of arguments is 0, it will calculate this argument to save proportion. For example, the source image is 800x600, and you pass 400 as width and 0 as height. Height will be calculated to preserve aspect ratio of the image, i.e. it will be 300.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.GetGraphics
member.summary: Gets the object associated with this .
member.returns: A object associated with this .

remarks.para: Several calls of this method will return the same object.
You can freely dispose the returned with this method, although it is not necessary. If you dispose this graphics object, next call of the method will create new instance of this class.
remarks.note: GDI cannot handle bitmaps with an alpha channel when it draws anything on it. As the high byte of 4-byte color must be zero in GDI, each pixel drawn with GDI becomes transparent. So now, if you try to call any drawing methods for the bitmaps with an alpha channel when using GDI, the exception will be thrown.

member.returns: A that represents the color of the specified pixel. The actual type of the returned object depends on color space of the bitmap. E.g. if the bitmap is RGB, actual type will be , etc.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.Handle
member.summary: Gets a GDI handle to this bitmap (HBITMAP).
member.value: The handle to this bitmap.

remarks.para: A handle to bitmap (HBITMAP) is often needed when it is necessary to use GDI functions to deal with the bitmap (as well as certain WinAPI functions which are responsible for the user interface rendering).
remarks.note: HBITMAP is available only if the bitmap is GDI-compatible, i.e. it has a pixel format which is supported by GDI. In other words, it will work for indexed bitmaps, as well as for 24-bit and 32-bit RGB bitmaps. If you have, say, CMYK bitmap, you should convert it to some GDI-compatible pixel format before using this property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.HasAlpha

member.value: true if the current pixel format supports alpha channel; otherwise false.

member.value: The height, in pixels, of this bitmap.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.IsEmpty

member.value: true if no data is loaded into bitmap; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified size and pixel format.
member.param: The width, in pixels, of the new .
The height, in pixels, of the new .

The pixel format for the new . If you specify indexed pixel format, uninitialized palette will be generated. You must fill entries by yourself. Palette will have maximum possible for given pixel format colors number (2 colors for 1-bit images, 16 colors for 4-bit images, and 256 colors for 8-bit images).

remarks.para: All pixel data are filled with 0. So if pixel format:

item.description: - image is fully transparent;
- image is filled with black color;
- image is filled with white color;
- image has color of the first palette entry.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.PixelFormat,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Color)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified size, pixel format, and background color.
member.param: The width, in pixels, of the new .
The height, in pixels, of the new .

The pixel format for the new . If you specify indexed pixel format, uninitialized palette will be generated. You must fill entries by yourself. Palette will have maximum possible for given pixel format colors number (2 colors for 1-bit images, 16 colors for 4-bit images, and 256 colors for 8-bit images).
The background color for the new .
member.remarks: If color space of the color does not fit color space of the pixel format, color is converted to necessary color space.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.PixelFormat,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Color,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorPalette)

Palette will have maximum possible for given pixel format colors number (2 colors for 1-bit images, 16 colors for 4-bit images, and 256 colors for 8-bit images).
The background color for the new .

The palette attached to the new . Note, this palette object is binded to bitmap, not copied. It means that if you later change anything in this palette object, changes will be reflected in the palette of bitmap.
member.remarks: If color space of the color does not fit color space of the pixel format, color is converted to necessary color space.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.Palette
member.summary: Gets a palette associated with this bitmap.
member.value: A associated with this bitmap.

remarks.para: A palette makes sense only for indexed bitmaps. No palette is returned if the bitmap is not indexed.

Once palette is attached to the bitmap (either in constructor or during color conversion), you cannot change entries number as well as attach another palette. In this case you need to initiate color conversion one more time. However it is not necessary if you need to modify values of palette entries.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.PixelFormat
member.summary: Gets a pixel format of the current bitmap.
member.value: A of the current bitmap.

remarks.para: You can use the following properties to get more detailed information about current pixel format:

item.description: Color space of pixels represented with current pixel format.
Whether current pixel format supports alpha channel (transparency information).
Whether color space of pixels represented with current pixel format is CMYK.
Whether color space of pixels represented with current pixel format is RGB.
Whether color space of pixels represented with current pixel format is grayscale.
Whether current pixel format is extended (16 bits per channel).
Whether current pixel format is indexed (palette-based).

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.Save(System.String)
member.summary: Saves this bitmap to the specified file.

member.remarks:
This method analyzes a file extension to determine the file format to save bitmap to. If an extention is unknown, this method fails (exception is thrown).>
Using this method is the same as creating an appropriate writer derived from the class and running it in synchronous mode.

overloads.summary: Saves the bitmap to the specified file.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.Save(System.String,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.WriterSettings)
member.summary: Saves this bitmap to the specified file using the provided settings.
member.param: A string that contains the name of the file to which to save this .

remarks.para: This method determines an output file format from the (regardless to the file extension).
Using this method is the same as creating appropriate writer derived from and running it in synchronous mode.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.Save(System.IO.Stream,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.WriterSettings)
member.summary: Saves this bitmap to the specified using the provided settings.
member.param: The where the image will be saved.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.SaveToClipboard
member.summary: Saves the bitmap into the clipboard.

remarks.para: To load the bitmap from the clipboard, use the method.
remarks.note: The copy of the bitmap is converted into the format which is supported by Windows so that other applications could load it. It means that if the bitmap has some non-standard pixel format (e.g. CMYK), it is automatically converted to 24-bit RGB. Therefore when you load the bitmap back from buffer using method, it may have another pixel format.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.Scan0
member.summary: Gets the pointer to the very first pixel of this bitmap.
member.value: The address of the first pixel of this bitmap.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.SetPixel(System.Int32,System.Int32,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Color)
member.summary: Sets the color of the specified pixel in this .
member.param: The x-coordinate of the pixel to set.
The y-coordinate of the pixel to set.

A that represents the color to assign to the specified pixel. It is recommended to make sure that this object has the same color space as the bitmap itself. If color spaces are not match (e.g. the bitmap is CMYK and this color is RGB), color will be automatically converted, but no color management will be applied.

remarks.para: This method was implemented for easy but slow access to pixels. It works ideally if you need to set one pixel value, for example, when you implement pencil tool.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.Statistics
member.summary: Gets an object providing methods which retrieve bitmap statistics (like histogram, etc).
member.value: A containing methods to retrieve bitmap statistics.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap.Stride
member.summary: Gets the width (in bytes) of the scan line.
member.value: The width of the scan line.
member.remarks: Since the property returns a number of pixels in single scan line, this property contains number of bytes in a scan line. As scan line may be aligned on four-bytes boundary, stride may differ from bitmap data width multiplied on number of bytes per pixel. That's why you should use this property to move to the same position on the next row instead of any other methods.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.BitmapStatisticsProvider
member.summary: Contains methods used to retrieve various bitmap statistics.
member.remarks: This class is accessible via the Bitmap.Statistics property. Its main feature is the ability to calculate a bitmap histogram. A histogram is an array of values that specify how much pixels has a luminosity (or other value that specifies pixel brightness level) equal to appropriate array index. It can be either calculated as histogram of bitmap luminosity ( method) or histogram of the channels sum ( method). Last method is used in Adobe Photoshop by default.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.BitmapStatisticsProvider.GetLuminosityHistogram
member.summary: Calculates and returns a histogram built from the bitmap luminosity.
member.returns: A containing luminosity histogram of this bitmap.
member.remarks: This histogram is equivalent to the histogram built from the same bitmap converted to grayscale.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.BitmapStatisticsProvider.GetSumHistogram
member.summary: Calculates and returns a histogram built from the sum of each channel luminosities of the pixel.
member.returns: A containing sum histogram of this bitmap.
member.remarks: This histogram type is used in Adobe Photoshop.

overloads.summary: Calculates and returns a sum histogram.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.BitmapStatisticsProvider.GetSumHistogram(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Channel)
member.summary: Calculates and returns a histogram built from luminosity of the single channel of the pixel.
member.param: A to build histogram for.
member.returns: A containing sum histogram of this bitmap.
member.remarks: This histogram type is used in Adobe Photoshop.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.BitmapStatisticsProvider.GetSumHistogram(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates and returns a histogram built from luminosity of the single channel of the pixel.
member.param: A channel number to build histogram for.
member.returns: A containing sum histogram of this bitmap.
member.remarks: This histogram type is used in Adobe Photoshop.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelCombiner
member.summary: Represents the base class for classes that create an image by combining several grayscale images.

remarks.para: Merging channels into a single image allows the creating of color images by combining several grayscale images. It is useful when, for example, you have 4 grayscale bitmaps prepared for printing (cyan, magenta, yellow, and black) and you need to make a color preview of the resulting image. The easiest way to merge channels into one image is to use one of the following descendant classes:

item.description: is specified to work with RGB images.
is specified to work with CMYK images.
is specified to work with grayscale images containing the alpha channel.

remarks.note: The merging channels must be of the same dimensions and resolution.

example.para: The following code creates a CMYK image by combining 4 grayscale bitmaps (one bitmap per color channel):

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the channel sources should be disposed along with this .
member.value: true if the channel sources (provided via the property) will be disposed along with this ; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelSplitter
member.summary: Represents the base class for classes that separate an image by color channels.

remarks.para: The result of channels separation is a number of grayscale images that are used to create printing plates. The number of images depends on the source image color space. You can use one of the following descendant classes, which allow the separation of images by channels:

item.description: is specified to work with RGB images.
is specified to work with CMYK images.
is specified to work with grayscale images containing the alpha channel.

remarks.para: The pixel format of the resulting image depends on the source image pixel format. The resulting image is if the source bitmap is not extended, and otherwise.

example.para: The following code separates a CMYK image by color channels:

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider
member.summary: Contains methods and properties providing access to bitmap channels.
member.remarks: This class is accessible via the Bitmap.Channels property. It allows you to extract bitmap channels to separate grayscale images, or replace some channel with another grayscale bitmap. You can do that using properties. Here you can set an alpha channel () or remove it ( method). Using method you can make alpha channel transparent at the areas with specified color.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.AlphaIndex
member.summary: Gets an index of the alpha channel.
member.value: The index of the alpha channel for the current bitmap.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.Channel(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Channel)
member.summary: Gets or sets the specified bitmap channel.
member.param: A to get or set.
member.value: A grayscale containing the specified channel. It always has the same dimensions as a source bitmap. Its pixel format is (if a source bitmap is not extended) or (if a source bitmap is extended).

overloads.summary: Gets or sets the specified bitmap channel.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of channels for the current bitmap.
member.value: The number of channels for the current bitmap.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.Channel(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets or sets the specified bitmap channel.
member.param: The number of channel to get or set.
member.value: class instance specifying a bitmap channel. It always has the same dimensions as source bitmap and its pixel format is (if source bitmap is not extended) or (if source bitmap is extended).

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.RemoveAlpha
member.summary: Removes the alpha channel from the current bitmap. Alpha channel is just discarded without affecting other channels.
member.remarks: This method does not flatten the alpha channel (it will be discarded without additional processing). If you need to flatten the alpha channel by blending it with some color, use version of this method.

overloads.summary: Removes the alpha channel from the current bitmap.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.RemoveAlpha(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Color)
member.summary: Removes the alpha channel from the current bitmap. The alpha channel is flattened using specified color (i.e. each pixel is alpha-blended with this color).
member.param: The to blend semi-transparent areas with.
member.remarks: If you do not want to flatten the alpha channel, use version of this method.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.ScaleAlpha(System.Single)
member.summary: Scales the alpha channel.
member.param: The scale factor (up to 100).

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.SetAlpha(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap)
member.summary: Sets the specified as the alpha channel to the current bitmap.
member.param: A grayscale to initialize alpha channel with. The bitmap should have the same dimensions and color depth as the current bitmap.
member.remarks: If alpha channel is already presented in the bitmap, this method will throw an exception. To check if alpha channel is available, use property of the class.

overloads.summary: Sets the alpha channel to the current bitmap.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.SetAlpha(System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the alpha channel to the current bitmap.
member.param: The opacity (in range [0, 1]) to initialize the alpha channel with. Depending on the channel color depth this value is normalized to 255 (for non-extended 8 bits per channel pixel formats) or to 65535 (for extended 16 bits per channel pixel formats).
member.remarks: If alpha channel is already presented in the bitmap, this method will throw an exception. To check if alpha channel is available, use property of the class.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.SwapChannels(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Swaps channels.
member.param: An array of channel indices sorted in the necessary order. E.g. if you need to swap blue and green channel in an RGB bitmap, this array should contain: (1, 0, 2).
member.remarks: If number of indices in channels argument is less than number of channels in the current bitmap, the rest channels will be unchanged. If there are more indices than current bitmap provides, all extra indices will be ignored.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ChannelsProvider.Transparentize(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Color,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets alpha values of pixels with a given color (and tolerant ones) to transparent.
member.param: A to transparentize.
The threshold in range [0, 1].
member.remarks: This method is very useful when you need to blend two images and "upper" image does not have alpha channel, but it has a background color. For example, you draw a logo placed in the center of the image on white background. In this case you set bgColor to white color. You can also adjust a threshold parameter to make colors close to white color semi-transparent (to get smooth colors). Besides of that threshold is useful when background color is not completely uniform (for example, you loaded JPEG file with low quality).

member.name: N:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs
member.summary: The namespace contains classes intended to work with files that have one or more images (frames) inside, such as multipage TIFF files, animated GIF, etc. These classes support a lot of file formats and allow working with metadata.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.AdobeResourceBlock
member.summary: Represents the Adobe image resource block.

remarks.para: Image resource blocks are one of the basic building units of several file formats, including Photoshop native file format, JPEG, and TIFF. Image resources are used to store non-pixel data associated with an image, such as pen tool paths.
remarks.note: Graphics Mill does not perform any validation of the resource data internal structure while encoding. So, you should provide correctly generated instances. Files containing incorrect Adobe image resource blocks can produce errors during opening or processing in Adobe applications.

example.para: The following code removes the thumbnail from Adobe image resource blocks and marks the image as copyrighted. Thumbnail block ID is 0x0409 and copyright flag ID is 0x040A.

member.summary: Gets or sets the data of this Adobe image resource block.
member.value: The data of this block.

remarks.note: Graphics Mill does not perform any validation of the resource data internal structure while encoding. So, you should provide correctly generated instances. Files containing incorrect Adobe image resource blocks can produce errors during opening or processing in Adobe applications.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.AdobeResourceDictionary
member.summary: Represents a dictionary of Adobe image resource blocks, each block is represented by the class.

remarks.para: Adobe applications (first of all Adobe Photoshop) store meta-information in so called Adobe image resource blocks. Graphics Mill provides the class to facilitate work with these data.

All functionality of this class is implemented in base class . To put or get some Adobe image resource block, you should use the property. Just pass ID of the Adobe image resource block as an argument into this property. Refer Adobe Photoshop File Formats Specification for exact Adobe image resource block ID values.

example.para: The following code removes the thumbnail from Adobe image resource blocks and marks the image as copyrighted. Thumbnail block ID is 0x0409 and copyright flag ID is 0x040A.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.BmpReader
member.summary: Contains methods and properties used to read BMP images.

remarks.para: BMP (Bitmap Picture) is a standard bitmap image format used to store digital images on Microsoft Windows operating systems. BMP files range from monochrome (1 bit per pixel) to 32 bit color images. The BMP format can store both indexed and full-color images in various color depths, and optionally with data compression, and color profiles.
BMP files can store only single image per file.

member.param: The name of the file to create this reader for.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.BmpSettings
member.summary: Contains all the possible BMP writing settings.

remarks.para: BMP (Bitmap Picture) is a standard bitmap image format used to store digital images on Microsoft Windows operating systems. BMP files range from monochrome (1 bit per pixel) to 32 bit color images. The BMP format can store both indexed and full-color images in various color depths, and optionally with data compression, and color profiles.
remarks.note: BMP supports only RLE compression for 4-bit and 8-bit images.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.BmpSettings.Compression
member.summary: Gets or sets a BMP compression type.
member.value: A to write the image with. The default value is .

remarks.para: BMP format has a very limited compression support. The table below specifies what compression types are supported by this format:

item.description: No limitations. Supported with all pixel formats allowed for BMP files.
Can be used only if the bitmap has 4 or 8 bits per pixel ( is , , or ).

remarks.para: BMP (Bitmap Picture) is a standard bitmap image format used to store digital images on Microsoft Windows operating systems. BMP files range from monochrome (1 bit per pixel) to 32 bit color images. The BMP format can store both indexed and full-color images in various color depths, and optionally with data compression, and color profiles.
BMP files can store only single image per file.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.CompressionType.Rle
member.summary: RLE compression algorithm.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.CompressionType.Unknown

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.CompressionType.Zip
member.summary: Deflate compression algorithm (the same is used in ZIP files).

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.DisposalMethod
member.summary: Contains values for disposal methods used in animated GIFs to specify what to do with a frame after it has been displayed.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.DisposalMethod.Background
member.summary: Restore to background color. The area used by a frame will be restored to the background color.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.DisposalMethod.None
member.summary: A frame will be left in place.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.DisposalMethod.NotSpecified
member.summary: The decoder is not required to take any action.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.DisposalMethod.Previous
member.summary: Restore to previous. The decoder is required to restore the area overwritten by a frame with what was there prior to rendering the frame.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.EpsWriter.AlphaThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets an alpha threshold for this .
member.value: An alpha threshold for this .

remarks.para: An image, drawn on the EPS document, may have the alpha channel specifying an opacity degree for each pixel. However, the EPS format cannot handle semi-transparency, that is, each pixel on EPS images can be displayed with full opacity or fully transparent. allows you to specify a threshold for transparency. Alpha threshold values are accepted in the range [0, 1]. If a pixel alpha value is greater than the threshold value, the pixel will be fully opaque; otherwise, it will be fully transparent.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.ExifDictionary
member.summary: Represents a dictionary of EXIF fields.
member.remarks: All functionality of this class is implemented in base class . To put or get some EXIF field, you should use the property. Just pass ID of the EXIF field as an argument into this property. Refer EXIF specification for exact field ID values. Alternatively you can use static members , , , , and others. Exact interpretations of these parameters can be found at EXIF specification. Currently specification 2.2 is supported.

example.para: The code below demonstrates how to extract and display both EXIF and IPTC data.

remarks.para: In general, frames store the following information:

item.description: Bitmap. You can get it using method.
Bitmap characteristics such as , , , etc. These properties will extract these data without loading entire bitmap into memory, so it works extremely fast.

remarks.note: These data are read from file only once. After you read some property, it is cached and next time it returns pre-loaded data.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.GifReader
member.summary: Contains methods and properties used to read GIF images.

remarks.para: GIF (Graphics Interchange Format) is a bitmap image format which works well for saving any type of grayscale or 256 color image. The color limitation makes the GIF format unsuitable for reproducing color photographs and other images with continuous color, but it is well-suited for simpler images such as graphics or logos with solid areas of color. The GIF image format supports animations and one-dimensional interlacing (a method of progressive displaying). GIF interlacing makes this format convenient for transmission of images across slow communication links.

GIF format can store only indexed images. As soon as it supports animation, it can contain multiple frames. Frame can have its own position, and a number of other paramaters, as delay time, disposal method, etc.

example.para: The following code reads a GIF image and saves its frames as separate PNG files:

member.summary: Gets an index of the background color.
member.value: An index of the background color in a global palette.

remarks.para: If this property is -1, the background color is disabled.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.GifWriter
member.summary: Contains methods and properties used to write GIF images (both static and animated).

remarks.para: GIF (Graphics Interchange Format) is a bitmap image format which works well for saving any type of grayscale or 256 color image. The color limitation makes the GIF format unsuitable for reproducing color photographs and other images with continuous color, but it is well-suited for simpler images such as graphics or logos with solid areas of color. The GIF image format supports animations and one-dimensional interlacing (a method of progressive displaying). GIF interlacing makes this format convenient for transmission of images across slow communication links.

GIF format can store only indexed images. As soon as it supports animation, it can contain multiple frames. Frame can have its own position, and a number of other paramaters, as delay time, disposal method, etc.

example.para: The following code creates an animated GIF file by grouping JPEG images:

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.IptcDictionary
member.summary: Represents a dictionary of IPTC fields.

remarks.para: All functionality of this class is implemented in base class . To put or get some IPTC field, you should use the property. Just pass ID of the IPTC field as an argument into this property. Refer IPTC specification for exact field ID values. Alternatively you can use static members , , , and others. Exact interpretations of these parameters can be found at IPTC specification. Currently specification 4.1 is supported.

IPTC tags consist of two numbers. For example, "2:25" means "Keywords". To be able to pass these numbers into , you should pack them as follows: first byte stores the second number (25 in this example), the second byte stores the first number (2 in this example). Other two bytes are not used.

example.para: The code below demonstrates how to extract and display both EXIF and IPTC data.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.JpegAlignToSampleSizeMode
member.summary: Contains possible values for JPEG sample size alignment.

remarks.para: This enumeration is used in the method of the class. It specifies whether to align only coordinates of the upper-left corner, or width and height also.
If you need just to crop an image and you do not want to use it as patch for another image, you can use the value. In this case the width and height of the cropping rectangle can be arbitrary.
However if you are going to put this image onto another (i.e. patch it), the width and height of this image must be aligned. In this case you should use value.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.JpegAlignToSampleSizeMode.Crop
member.summary: Only coordinates of the upper-left corner will be aligned. Width and height will not be aligned. Should be used for if no consequent is implied. Width and height still may be changed to preserve right and bottom position of the input rectangle. However it will not be aligned.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.JpegAlignToSampleSizeMode.Patch
member.summary: The entire rectangle is aligned. You should use this value if you are preparing a rectangle (offset and bitmap dimensions) for the method.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.JpegReader
member.summary: Contains methods and properties used to read JPEG images.

remarks.para: JPEG (Joint Photographic Experts Group) is the most popular bitmap image format for storing digital photos using lossy compression. The JPEG format was designed for compressing either grayscale or full-color images of real-world scenes. It supports the sequential and progressive compression schemes, subsampling, and setting a quality range from 0 to 100.
JPEG files can also contain Adobe resources, XMP, EXIF and IPTC data. However it does not support multiple images in the single file.
JPEG images support three main color spaces:

item.description: RGB;
CMYK;
Grayscale;

remarks.para: It does not support indexed images, as well as extended (16 bit per channel) pixel formats.

example.para: The following code saves JPEG file with the quality value set to 90, disabled chroma subsampling, and the enabled JPEG progressive technique.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.JpegSettings
member.summary: Contains all the possible JPEG writing settings.

remarks.para: The main JPEG encoder setting is a quality/file size ratio. It is specified with property. This property accepts values in range [0, 100] where 0 means the lowest quality (but smallest file size) and 100 means the highest quality (but largest file size).

Besides of this you can specify is JPEG should be progressive (using ). It allows the browsers to display the JPEG file while it is being downloaded (displaying more and more details upon new file portions download). Unfortunately this feature is not supported with Internet Explorer browser.

Another compression setting can be changed via property. Chroma subsampling is one of the compression methods used in JPEG. It is based on the specific of the human vision and allows to reduce size of the result file by storing color information at lower resolution than luminance information. In most cases this tradeoff will not be noticeable to the human. But sometimes such information loss may be significant (e.g. for some classes of image processing algorithms) and chroma subsampling should be turned off. Chroma subsampling is enabled by default.
You can also provide meta-information for encoding. Use , and properties to specify corresponding metadata objects.

example.para: The following code saves JPEG file with the quality value set to 90, disabled chroma subsampling, and the enabled JPEG progressive technique.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.JpegWriter
member.summary: Contains methods and properties used to write JPEG images.

remarks.para: JPEG (Joint Photographic Experts Group) is the most popular bitmap image format for storing digital photos using lossy compression. The JPEG format was designed for compressing either grayscale or full-color images of real-world scenes. It supports the sequential and progressive compression schemes, subsampling, and setting a quality range from 0 to 100.
JPEG files can also contain Adobe resources, XMP, EXIF and IPTC data. However it does not support multiple images in the single file.
JPEG images support three main color spaces:

item.description: RGB;
CMYK;
Grayscale;

remarks.para: It does not support indexed images, as well as extended (16 bit per channel) pixel formats.

example.para: The following code saves JPEG file with the quality value set to 90, disabled chroma subsampling, and the enabled JPEG progressive technique.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.LosslessJpeg
member.summary: Contains methods and properties used to apply lossless operations on JPEG images.

remarks.para: This class is intended to operate with JPEG images without recompression. It is useful if you need to modify metadata only (without modifying the image), rotate or/and flip recompression, or recompress only a part of an image. For example, if you add a text caption on the image, it makes sense to recompress only the part of image where the caption is placed and leave all the rest of image intact.
The following lossless operations are supported:

item.term: Changing Adobe resources, XMP, EXIF or IPTC data
item.description: use , , and properties to modify metadata, and then use methods to save changes.
use the method.

item.term: Recompressing only a part of the image
item.description: use , , and . See remarks for these methods for more details.

remarks.para: According to JPEG specification an image is represented by blocks of pixels so-called JPEG Minimum Coded Units (MCU). Typically MCU size is a number divisible by 8. That fact allows performing lossless rotation: MCU blocks are rearranged in new order as well as the order of pixels is changed inside each MCU. Examine the situation when width or height of an image is non-divisible by MCU size, it means that the last column or row contains partially-filled MCU blocks. Such images do not support some types of rotation. They will be cropped during transformation and width and height of the resulting image will be divisible by MCU size. If you need to know whether dimensions of your image will be changed after a transformation, you can use the method. This method indicates whether dimensions will be changed taking into account the dimensions of currently opened image and the desired type of transformation.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.LosslessJpeg.AdobeResources
member.summary: Gets or sets Adobe image resource blocks stored in the opened image.
member.value: A containing Adobe image resource blocks stored in the opened image.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.LosslessJpeg.AlignToMCUSize(System.Drawing.Point,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap)
member.summary: Aligns coordinates of the point and bitmap to JPEG Minimum Coded Units (MCU).
member.param: A at which the bitmap should be placed. It will be used as a location of the upper-left corner of the input rectangle.
A to aligne. Its width and height will be used as dimensions of the input rectangle.
member.returns: A which contains coordinates aligned to MCU. It is always greater or equal than the input rectangle formed by the offset and dimensions of the bitmap.
member.remarks: This method is used when you need overwrite some portion of JPEG image by some bitmap. Since JPEG compressed data is stored in blocks (samples) of several pixels (typically 8, 16, or other number divisible by 8), you cannot write bitmap by arbitrary coordinates. That's why you need to align coordinates by JPEG Minimum Coded Units (MCU).

overloads.summary: Aligns coordinates to JPEG Minimum Coded Units (MCU).

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.LosslessJpeg.AlignToMCUSize(System.Drawing.Rectangle,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.JpegAlignToSampleSizeMode)
member.summary: Aligns the rectangle to JPEG Minimum Coded Units (MCU).
member.param: A to align to MCU.
A specifying whether to align only coordinates of the upper-left corner, or width and height also. See the Remerks section for details.
member.returns: A aligned to MCU. It is always greater or equal than the input rectangle.

remarks.para: This method is used when you need overwrite some portion of JPEG image by some bitmap. Since JPEG compressed data is stored in blocks (samples) of several pixels (typically 8, 16, or other number divisible by 8), you cannot write bitmap by arbitrary coordinates. That's why you need to align coordinates by JPEG Minimum Coded Units (MCU).
If you need just to crop an image and you do not want to use it as patch for another image, you can use the value. In this case the width and height of the cropping rectangle can be arbitrary.
However if you are going to put this image onto another (i.e. patch it), the width and height of this image must be aligned. In this case you should use value.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.MetadataDictionary
member.summary: Represents a dicitonary of image metadata, such as EXIF, IPTC, etc.

remarks.para: This abstract class contains partial implementation of the , , and classes. It is used to read, write, and modify metadata stored in images.

Metadata is stored as pairs of keys and values. Key is an EXIF/IPTC tag or image block ID, value is an actual value stored at this key. To get a piece of data from the collection use property or method (for several items). To check whether an item with certain key is available at the dictionary, you can use method. You can also get all keys or all values through or property correspondingly. For easier displaying, you can convert key into human-readable text string using method.

Typically you get this class instance from , , or property of the . You can also create a new empty instance of , or class and put necessary details using method. After that you can put this dictionary into , or property of the or class. This way you can save updated EXIF data into the image file.

An array of to add into the dictionary.

remarks.para: To check whether the element with such key exists, use method.
An alternative way to add new elements into the dictionary is to use property.

member.returns: An array of elements with a given key.

remarks.para: The essential difference from property is that this method returns an array, even if only one element is stored at this key. In contrast, property returns the element itself, and if several elements are available at the specified key, it returns the first one.
Therefore it is preferrable to use this method instead of . However if you do not care about handling all values, you still can use since it has simpler syntax.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.MetadataEnumerator
member.summary: Enumerates the elements of this dictionary.

remarks.para: This class implements the interface.

Initially, the enumerator is positioned before the first element in the collection. At this position, calling throws an exception. Therefore, you must call to advance the enumerator to the first element of the collection before reading the value of .

After the end of the collection is passed, the enumerator is positioned after the last element in the collection, and calling returns false. If the last call to returned false, calling throws an exception.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.PdfSettings
member.summary: Contains all the possible PDF writing settings.

remarks.para: PDF (Portable Document Format) was developed by Adobe Systems, Inc. for secure and reliable distribution of electronic documents independent of software, hardware, and operating system. In general, a PDF file includes a complete description of a fixed-layout flat document such as the text, fonts, graphics, and other information needed to display it.
Graphics Mill allows writing PDF files only. You can specify compression type for it using property. If you are using compression, you can also specify a JPEG quality via the property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.PdfSettings.Compression
member.summary: Gets or sets PDF compression type.
member.value: A to write the image with. The default value is .

remarks.para: PDF format supports the following compression types:

item.description: No limitations. Supported with all pixel formats allowed for PDF files.
No limitations. Supported with all pixel formats allowed for PDF files.
Can be used only with those pixel formats which are supported by JPEG (non-extended and non-indexed grayscale, RGB, and CMYK images). To adjust JPEG quality, use property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.PdfSettings.IsPrintingEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the image should be printed when the user opens it.
member.value: true if the image should be printed when the user opens it; otherwise, false.

The JPEG quality in range [0, 100]. Makes sense if only the compression is set to .

member.param: A to write the image with. You can change it later through the property.

true if the image should be printed when the user opens it; otherwise, false. You can change it later through the property.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.PdfWriter
member.summary: Contains methods and properties used to write PDF file.

remarks.para: PDF (Portable Document Format) was developed by Adobe Systems, Inc. for secure and reliable distribution of electronic documents independent of software, hardware, and operating system. In general, a PDF file includes a complete description of a fixed-layout flat document such as the text, fonts, graphics, and other information needed to display it.
You can create multiple pages in the PDF file.

member.summary: Adds a new page with the given width and height to the PDF file.

overloads.summary: Adds a new page to the PDF file.

member.param: The width of the page to add.
The height of the page to add.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.PdfWriter.AddPage(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Drawing.RectangleF,System.Drawing.RectangleF,System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Adds a new page with the given width, height, and page boundaries to the PDF file.
member.param: The width of the page to add.
The height of the page to add.
A rectangle defining the region surrounding the content which is to be clipped when the PDF page is displayed or printed. Crop Box specifies the visible part of the content.

A rectangle defining the dimensions of the fulfilled page. In contrast with the crop box, the trim box is important because it defines the actual page size used for positioning pages on a press sheet.
A rectangle defining the region to which the contents of the page should be clipped when output in a production environment. By default, the bleed box equals the crop box.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.PngReader
member.summary: Contains methods and properties used to read PNG images.

remarks.para: PNG (Portable Network Graphics) was created to replace the obsolete GIF format due to a legal problem caused by the LZW algorithm used in GIF. In comparison with GIF, the PNG format has three main advantages:

item.description: alpha channel (variable transparency),
gamma correction (cross-platform control of image brightness),
two-dimensional interlacing (method of progressive displaying).

remarks.para: PNG supports palette-based images with palettes of 24-bit RGB or 32-bit RGBA colors, grayscale images (with or without alpha channel), and full-color non-palette-based images with or without alpha channel.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode
member.summary: Contains blending modes.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Color
member.summary: Color blending mode. Keeps the color of the active layer, and blends the hue and saturation (the color) of the active layer with the luminance of the lower layers.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.ColorBurn
member.summary: Color Burn blending mode. Darker than Multiply, with more highly saturated mid-tones and reduced highlights.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.ColorDodge
member.summary: Color Dodge blending mode. Brighter than the Screen blend mode. Results in an intense, contrasty color-typically results in saturated mid-tones and blown highlights.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Darken
member.summary: Darken blending mode. If the pixels of the selected layer are darker than the ones on the layers below, they are kept in the image. If the pixels in the layer are lighter, they are replaced with the tones on the layers below.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.DarkerColor
member.summary: Darker Color blending mode. Similar to the Darken blend mode, but darkens on the composite channel, instead of separate RGB color channels.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Difference
member.summary: Difference blending mode. Subtracts a pixel on the active layer, from an equivalent pixel in the composite view of the underlying layer, and results in only absolute numbers.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Dissolve
member.summary: Dissolve blending mode. The Dissolve blend mode on acts on transparent and partially transparent pixels - it treats transparency as a pixel pattern and applies a diffusion dither pattern.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Divide
member.summary: Divide blending mode. Divides a pixel on the active layer, from an equivalent pixel in the underlying layers on a channel by channel basis.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Exclusion
member.summary: Exclusion blending mode. Subtracts a pixel on the active layer, from an equivalent pixel in the composite view of the underlying layers, and results in only absolute numbers (the subtraction never produces a negative number).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.HardLight
member.summary: Hard Light blending mode. Uses a combination of the Linear Dodge blend mode on the lighter pixels, and the Linear Burn blend mode on the darker pixels. It uses a half-strength application of these modes, and logic similar to the Overlay blend mode, but favors the active layer, as opposed to the underlying layers.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.HardMix
member.summary: Hard Mix blending mode. Uses the Linear Light blend mode set to a threshold, so for each RGB color channel, pixels in each channel are converted to either all black or all white. Once the math is applied to each separate channel, and the composite channel is created, the resulting composite can contain up to 8 colors: Red, Green, Blue, Cyan, Magenta, Yellow, Black and White.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Hue
member.summary: Hue blending mode. Keeps the Hue of the active layer, and blends the luminance and saturation of the underlying layers (you basically get the image from the lower layer with the colors of the top layer).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Lighten
member.summary: Lighten blending mode. If the pixels of the selected layer are lighter than the ones on the layers below, they are kept in the image (the opposite of the Darken blend mode). If the pixels in the layer are darker, they are replaced with the pixels on the layers below (they show through to the selected layer).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.LighterColor
member.summary: Lighter Color blending mode.Similar to the Lighten blend mode, but lightens on the composite channel, instead of separate color channels. Compares each pixel and gives you the lighter of the two (and usually results in harsher transitions).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.LinearBurn
member.summary: Linear Burn blending mode. Darker than Multiply, but less saturated than Color Burn.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.LinearDodge
member.summary: Linear Dodge blending mode. Brighter than the Color Dodge blend mode, but less saturated and intense. This mode "Adds" the luminance levels.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.LinearLight
member.summary: Linear Light blending mode. Uses a combination of the Linear Dodge blend mode on the lighter pixels, and the Linear Burn blend mode on the darker pixels (a half-strength application of both modes).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Luminosity
member.summary: Luminosity blending mode. Keeps the luminance of the active layer, and blends it with hue and saturation (the color) of the composite view of the layers below. This results in the colors of the underlying layers being blended with the active layer, and replacing them.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Multiply
member.summary: Multiply blending mode. Works by multiplying the luminance levels of the current layer's pixels with the pixels in the layers below.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Normal
member.summary: Normal blending mode. The normal mode where no math is applied.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Overlay
member.summary: Overlay blending mode. Uses a combination of the Screen blend mode on the lighter pixels, and the Multiply blend mode on the darker pixels. It uses a half-strength application of these modes, and the mid-tones (50% gray) becomes transparent.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Pass
member.summary: Pass Through blending mode. It is the default blend mode for a layer group.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.PinLight
member.summary: PinLight blending mode. Uses a combination of the Lighten blend mode on the lighter pixels, and the Darken blend mode on the darker pixels (a half-strength application of both modes). If the dark pixels on the active layer are darker than the dark pixels on the underlying layers, they will be visible, if they are not, they drop away. If the pixels on the active layer are lighter than the pixels on the underlying layers, they will also be visible, if they are not, they drop away.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Saturation
member.summary: Saturation blending mode. Keeps the saturation of the active layer, and blends the luminosity and hue from the underlying layers - where colors from the active layer are saturated, they will appear using the luminosity and hue from the underlying layers.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Screen
member.summary: Screen blending mode. Similar to the Lighten blend mode, but brighter and removes more of the dark pixels, and results in smoother transitions. Works somewhat like the Multiply blend mode, in that it multiplies the light pixels (instead of the dark pixels like the Multiply blend mode does).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.SoftLight
member.summary: SoftLight blending mode. Uses a combination of the Screen blend mode on the lighter pixels, and the Multiply blend mode on the darker pixels (a half-strength application of both modes).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.Subtract
member.summary: Subtract blending mode. Subtracts a pixel on the active layer, from an equivalent pixel in the composite view of the underlying layers.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.BlendMode.VividLight
member.summary: Vivid Light blending mode. Uses a combination of the Color Dodge Mode on the lighter pixels, and the Color Burn blend mode on the darker pixels (a half-strength application of both modes).

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.FrameType
member.summary: Contains possible types of PSD layers (i.e. frames of ).

remarks.para: Text layers can be interpreted as raster ones which include additional meta-information about the text stored in this frame (like the text string, font and paragraph settings, etc). You can get the bitmap from such frames which will contain rasterized text string.
When you iterate through frames of the PSD file, be sure to skip unknown and group layers. It is necessary to avoid problems with extracting bitmaps which are not available in such layers.

member.summary: Unsupported type of layer (like adjustment layers, etc).

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.PsdReader
member.summary: Contains methods and properties used to read PSD images.

remarks.para: PSD (Photoshop Document) is a native bitmap file format of the Adobe Photoshop program using lossless data compression. This format is a de facto standard for designers all over the world. The PSD image format is rather complex and stores a lot of layers and additional data (image layers, text layers, applied effects, etc.).

example.para: The following code opens a PSD file, iterates through its layers, and saves bitmaps from the raster layers to separate PNG files:

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.PsdReader.Frames
member.summary: Gets a collection of plain (raster and text) layers.
member.value: A containing raster and text layers from this PSD image.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.PsdReader.GroupedFrames
member.summary: Gets a collection of plain grouped layers.
member.value: A containing grouped layers from this PSD image.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.PsdReader.Height
member.summary: Gets an entire image height.
member.value: The entire image height (in pixels).

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.PsdReader.MergedImageFrame
member.summary: Gets a merged copy from this PSD image.
member.value: A containing a merged copy of all visible layers.
member.remarks: If a source PSD file doesn't contain a merged copy this property returns null.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.PsdReader.SpotChannels
member.summary: Gets a collection of spot channels from the PSD file.
member.value: A containing spot channels.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.PsdReader.MergeLayers
member.summary: Creates a merged copy of all visible layers.
member.returns: A containing a merged copy of all visible layers.
member.remarks: This method is useful when a source PSD image does not contain a merged copy of its layers (i.e. the returns null).

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.Psd.PsdReader.MergeLayers(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.PipelineElement)
member.summary: Creates a merged copy of all visible layers and pass it into a given pipeline.
member.param: A to pass a merged copy to.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffChannelType
member.summary: Contains possible extra channel types.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffChannelType.Alpha
member.summary: Unassociated alpha data is transparency information that logically exists independently of an image. Unassociated alpha is additional information, which can be removed or edited.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffChannelType.Color
member.summary: Color data.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffChannelType.PremultipliedAlpha
member.summary: Associated alpha data is opacity information. The color information of each pixel is additionally premultiplied with the value of alpha channel. If this channel data is removed or edited, the image changes. Storing data in premultiplied format allows compositing operations to be implemented more efficiently.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffChannelType.Undefined
member.summary: Unspecified data can contain color information in addition to primary colors or non-color information.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffExtraChannel
member.summary: Represents the TIFF extra channel retrieved from an image.
member.remarks: One of the most important features of the TIFF image format is the extra channels support. Extra channels are typically used to specify non-color information (such as image opacity), highlight some image area, or apply additional inks (such as gold, silver, etc.) in printing solutions.

example.para: The following code reads a TIFF image, extracts an extra channel from it, and saves the channel's bitmap as a JPEG image.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffExtraChannel.ChannelType
member.summary: Gets a type of this extra channel.
member.value: A of this extra channel.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffExtraChannelCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection of TIFF extra channels.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffReader
member.summary: This class enables you to read TIFF images.

remarks.para: TIFF format is one of the most comprehensive image formats. It was designed to promote the interchange of digital image data. The general scenario TIFF format was invented for, assumes that scanning or painting software creates a TIFF file, which can then be read and incorporated into a document or publication by an application such as a desktop publishing package. It is also widely used to retrieve facsimile messages.

This image format is rather versatile and have a lot of modifications. It supports most Graphics Mill pixel formats even such exotic ones like . It also can store multiple images in the single file (mostly used for fax images and other documents stored as 1-bit bitmaps).
TIFF files can also contain Adobe resources, XML, EXIF and IPTC data.

example.para: The following code snippet demonstrates how to split a multiframe image file into separate JPEG files:

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified .
member.param: The to create this reader for.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffReader.TreatFirstExtraChannelAsAlpha
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the reader should interpret the first extra channel as alpha channel in pixel data.
member.value: true if the reader interprets the first extra channel as alpha; otherwise, false. The default value is true.

remarks.para: For example, assume you read an image contained three color channels (RGB) and two extra ones. If this property is true, the image loaded from frame using method will be interpreted as ARGB (RGB + alpha). collection will contain one extra channel in this case. Otherwise, if the property is false, it will be interpreted as RGB with two extra channels.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffSettings
member.summary: Contains all the possible TIFF writing settings.

remarks.para: The main TIFF writing settings is a compression type. To change compression type use property. This property accepts members of the enumeration.

Another setting which can be specified is alpha premultiplication which has meaning only when saving image with alpha channel. You can turn it on or off using property. The default value of this property is false and content of the alpha channel is simply stored along with color channels of the image by default. The second way is to store image with "associated" alpha channel. This way implies that not only alpha channel itself will be written into the file, but also color channels of each pixel will be premultiplied with the corresponding alpha channel value.

You should use TIFF files with associated alpha if you have software which gain some benefit from them. For example, TIFF files with premultiplied alpha are correctly shown as partially transparent images in Adobe Photoshop, while images with unassociated alpha are shown as non transparent images with additional channel. But you should take into account that premultiplication is slow and introduces rounding errors. So you should not set this property to true without reason.
You can also provide meta-information. Use , and properties to specify corresponding metadata objects.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffSettings.AdobeResources
member.summary: Gets or sets Adobe image resource blocks to write into the image.
member.value: A containing Adobe image resource blocks to write into the image.

member.summary: Gets or sets a compression type to write the image with.
member.value: A to write the image with. The default value is .

remarks.para: TIFF format supports the following compression types:

item.description: No limitations.
For 1-bit images only.
For 1-bit images only.
For 1-bit images only.
Can be used only with those pixel formats which are supported by JPEG (non-extended and non-indexed grayscale, RGB, and CMYK images). To adjust JPEG quality, use property.
Has no limitations, but works better with indexed images.
No limitations.
No limitations.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffSettings.Exif
member.summary: Gets or sets EXIF data collection to write into the image.
member.value: A containing EXIF data collection to write into the image.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffSettings.Iptc
member.summary: Gets or sets IPTC data collection to write into the image.
member.value: A containing IPTC data collection to write into the image.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.TiffSettings.IsAlphaPremultiplied
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to premultiply image with alpha channel during writing or not.
member.value: true if color channels of each pixel are premultiplied with corresponding alpha channel; otherwise, false. The default value is false.

remarks.para: This property has meaning only when you save an image with alpha channel.
TIFF specification defines two ways of alpha channel storing.

list.item: Unassociated alpha. The content of the alpha channel is simply stored along with color channels of the image. This is default behaviour.
Associated alpha. The content of the alpha channel is stored into the file, but color channels of each pixel are premultiplied with the corresponding alpha channel value.

remarks.para: You should use TIFF files with associated alpha if you have software which gain some benefit from them (for example, unassociated alpha channel will be shown as separate channel in Adobe Photoshop, while image with associated alpha will be shown as image with transparency). But you should take into account that premultiplying process is slow and introduces rounding errors. So you should not set this property to true without reason.

There is no difference for you between files with "associated" and "unassociated" alpha if you process them with Graphics Mill. class implementation takes into account this option during image reading and performs demultiplication if necessary. So you will always get usual object with "unassociated" alpha.
