member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.XmpData
member.summary: Represents an XMP tree.

remarks.para: This class can be used for two purposes:

item.description: Parse XMP data and extract the specific fields values (nodes).
Build or modify existing XMP tree by adding/removing/editing nodes.

remarks.para: XMP is an XML-based tree-like format of metadata storage. This class allows to load XML containing XMP data (with a constructor or the method). After the XMP string is loaded, a hierarchical set of nodes is formed. You can iterate each node in the collection and drill down into its children to get information about some specific node.

To add nodes to this tree, use the method. Any object that is a descendant of the class can be added to the tree. Items are removed with the method. After you build a tree of XMP fields, you can get it as an XML string which can be passed to any writer object that supports XMP data (JPEG, TIFF).

This method only clears the values of the elements; it does not delete the elements themselves.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Codecs.XmpData.Load(System.String)
member.summary: Creates an XMP tree based on the provided XML code.
member.param: An XML code with the XMP data.

remarks.para: Typically you get the string with XMP data from a JPEG or TIFF reader class. After that you pass this string to this method. As soon as XMP data is loaded to the class, you can easily get specific fields value.

If you edit XMP data (add, remove, or modify nodes) and want to save it back, use the method. It will return the XML string which you will be able to pass to the Xmp property of an appropriate writer.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Color.ChannelCount
member.summary: Gets a number of channels available in this color.
member.value: The number of channels available in this color.
member.remarks: Alpha channel is always available. That's why RGB colors always return 4 (three color channels + alpha channel), grayscale color returns 2 (luminosity channel + alpha channel), etc.

member.summary: Gets or sets a color profile associated with this color.
member.value: A associated with the color.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Color.ColorSpace
member.summary: Gets a color space of the color.
member.value: The of the color.
member.remarks: Each class derived from the represents its own color space. It means that if, for example, this property returns , you can cast this variable to class. However casting to derived classes is considered as bad style from object-oriented point of view, so it is recommended to use it only if it is necessary indeed.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Color.IsTransparent

Therefore you can write only single line of code to make a tone correction.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorAdjustmentProvider.HistogramEqualize
member.summary: Applies a histogram equalization to the bitmap.

remarks.para: Histogram equalization algorithm is used for automatically enhancing the image contrast. The main idea of this algorithm is to build a look-up table (LUT) which makes the bitmap histogram equalized (all histogram entries are equal each other). Actually the histogram is never equalized absolutely, however this algorithm makes it as much as possible.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorManagementProvider
member.summary: Contains methods and properties used to provide color management.

remarks.para: This class is accessible via the Bitmap.ColorManagement property. You should use it if you need to apply color management during color conversions, drawing, and other operations where it is applicable.

To choose the color management engine, use the property. You can specify an output profile ( property) and profile for target device ( property). A color management intent parameter is accessible through the property.
After you set color management up, you can apply color conversions using the methods.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorManagementProvider.BackgroundColor
member.summary: Gets or sets a background color used when alpha channel is flatten.
member.value: The background color. The default value is white color.
member.remarks: This property makes sense only when you convert from pixel format which supports alpha channel to pixel format which does not.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorManagementProvider.ColorManagementEngine
member.summary: Gets or sets color management engine which will be used during image transformation. Graphics Mill supports the following engines: LittleCMS and Adobe CMM. The property also allows disabling color management and perform transformation without color matching.
member.value: A to use.

remarks.para: Color management will be applied during transformation of image between color formats in case if all the following conditions are met:

item.description: This property is set to or .

The which needs to be transformed has a initialized with a correct color profile (e.g. it is embedded color profile loaded from image file, or this property is initialized after the image has been loaded or created).
An output color profile is initialized via the property.

remarks.para: If you do not need to apply color management during image transformation, set this property to .

member.summary: Gets or sets the target device profile used for chain transformations.

remarks.para: This profile is used to preview on one device how the image will be looking at another one. For example, let's assume you want to display on the screen how the image will be looking after being printed by specific printer. In this case set:

item.description: to monitor profile.
to printer profile.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorManagementProvider.TransparentIndexThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets a transparency threshold.
member.value: The threshold is range [0, 255]. The default value is 128.

remarks.para: When building a palette during color reduction for an image which should be saved to GIF, you need to have the only one transparent color. However during color reduction you may get a number of colors with a different level of transparency. To avoid this, use this property. All alpha channel values which are greater or equal to this value will be changed to 255 (fully opaque), otherwise it will be 0.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorPalette
member.summary: Represents a palette, i.e. an array of color values.

remarks.para: Color palettes are used in indexed bitmaps to store colors. Each pixel of the indexed bitmap is an index you should pass to to get an actual color this pixel represents. These indices should not exceed total number of palette entries which you can get through property.

Since the palettes never store more than 256 entries, only few of 16 millions 24-bit RGB colors are available in the palette. That's why if you need change a color of some pixel, you cannot pass arbitrary color. You should find nearest color in the palette and pass its index instead. To convert the color into index in this palette, you can use method. Note, this method works quite slow, that's why you should cache nearest index if possible.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorPalette.Clone
member.summary: Returns a full copy of this instance.
member.returns: An object containing a full copy of this color palette.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorPalette.Count
member.summary: Returns a number of colors in the palette.
member.value: The number of colors in the palette.
member.remarks: A number of colors in palette depends on the color depth of the image where it is used. 1-bit bitmaps can have only 2 colors, 4-bit bitmaps - 16 colors, 8-bit bitmaps - 256 colors. 8 bit is a maximum bit depth for indexed images, so this property never exceed 256.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorPalette.SetKeyColor(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.RgbColor)
member.summary: Makes a palette entry which is closest to a given color transparent.
member.param: A which should be transparent.

remarks.para: Alpha channel of a given entry will be dropped to 0, alpha channels of all other entries will be set to 255. This way palette will contain a single transparent color.
This method can be treated as analogue of transform for non-indexed image.
remarks.note: Setting transparent index works noticeable faster than setting transparent color (which actually calls slow method). That's why it is highly recommended to pass index instead of color if possible.

overloads.summary: Makes a palette entry transparent.

This method can be treated as analogue of transform for non-indexed image.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.ColorProfile
member.summary: Represents the ICC color profile used to provide color management.

remarks.para: This class encapsulates an ICC color profile. Typically it is used as a parameter in color management classes/methods, however it also has a number of useful properties that allow obtaining extra details about the profile. In particular, you can get metainformation such as , , (a device kind the profile is intended for), , and . You can also get a the profile is made for.
You can create instance in four ways:

item.description: creates a instance from specified file.
creates a instance from the color profile associated with monitor.
Creates a instance from a standard sRGB color profile.
creates a instance from the standard Adobe RGB (1998) color profile.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Histogram
member.summary: Represents a bitmap histogram.

remarks.para: Histograms are widely used in imaging. It is represented as an array which contains values specifying as much items as intensity levels are supported by a bitmap (i.e. for 8 bit per channel bitmaps it will be 256, for 16 bit per channel - 65356). Each histogram entry stores a number of bitmap pixels which have the same intensity level as index of this entry. For example, the first histogram entry contains a number of black pixels (i.e. pixels having zero intensity level). Entry at index 192 contains a number of pixels with intensity level equal to 192.

When Graphics Mill builds a histogram for a grayscale bitmap, it uses pixel value as an intensity level. For color bitmaps (RGB, CMYK) several algorithms for calculating intensity level of each pixel are available. Graphics Mill implements two of them:

item.description: Pixel color is converted to grayscale and this value is used as intensity level. This conversion is made by adding all channel values multiplied at weights (all weights are normalized at 1). These weights are selected with taking into consideration specifics of human vision, that's why it provides more precise result comparing to the Sum method. You can build luminosity histogram using method.

Graphics Mill calculates sum of all channels of the pixel and divides it by the count of channels. The advantage of this method is a possibility to exclude some channel from the intensity level calculation. This way you can get a histogram, e.g., for one or two channels. This method is implemented at Adobe Photoshop. To build sum histogram, use some of overload of method.

remarks.para: Histogram enables you to estimate image contrast programmatically. Also you can get some other characteristics (mean brightness, standard deviation, median, etc).
Histogram is used (explicitly or implicitly) in a number of Graphics Mill transforms, such as , , (in automatic mode), etc.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Pipeline
member.summary: Represents a collection of s.

remarks.para: Pipelines allow reading and writing image files and processing them without the necessity to load a whole bitmap into memory. This essentially means that you can process large images without getting out-of-memory errors, even on an x86 platform. Pipelines offer the following benefites:

item.description: Within a pipeline, an image is processed stripe by stripe - a portion of image data having the same width as the original and height selected by Graphics Mill for optimal processing.
Temporary bitmap data may be dumped to the hard drive if it is necessary.
Descriptive image processing sequence, meaning that image data flows through the pipeline from one transformation to another, so each next element receives the result of the previous processing.

Ability to build branched pipelines. This is an approach whereby the transformation result can be passed to an arbitrary number of receivers and each of them can process the received data in its own way. For example, you can open an image and save it to JPEG and PNG files, or produce multiple thumbnails of different size at one pass. See the Examples section for details.

example.para: This code sample reads an image from JPEG file, crops a square from its center, adjusts brightness, and writes the result to another file.
The following code shows how to create two 128x128 and 2048x2048 thumbnails for a single image.

Temporary bitmap data may be dumped to the hard drive if it is necessary.

Ability to build branched pipelines. This is an approach whereby the transformation result can be passed to an arbitrary number of receivers and each of them can process the received data in its own way. For example, you can open an image and save it to JPEG and PNG files, or produce multiple thumbnails of different size at one pass. See the Examples section for details.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.PixelFormat
member.summary: Represents a pixel format supported by Graphics Mill.

remarks.note: GDI cannot handle bitmaps with an alpha channel () when it draws anything on it. As the high byte of 4-byte color must be zero in GDI, each pixel drawn with GDI becomes transparent. So now, if you try to call any drawing methods for the bitmaps with an alpha channel when using GDI, the exception will be thrown.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Rational
member.summary: Represents signed rational numbers.

remarks.para: Rational number is a number which may be represented as a division of two natural numbers. For example, 3/4, 2/1, 1/6, etc. Not all fractional numbers are rational. For example, a Pi number is irrational (i.e. cannot be represented as a division of two natural numbers).
This class provides an access to and . A cannot be zero.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Rational.Dividend
member.summary: Gets or sets a dividend of the rational number.
member.value: The dividend of the rational number (i.e. if represent rational number as p/q, dividend is p).

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Rational.Divider
member.summary: Gets or sets a divider of the rational number.
member.value: The divider of the rational number (i.e. if represent rational number as p/q, divider is q).
member.remarks: Divider cannot equal to zero.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.RgbChannelSplitter
member.summary: Separates a RGB image by color channels.

remarks.para: The result of channels separation is a number of grayscale images that are used to create printing plates. The number of images depends on the source image color space. The pixel format of the resulting image depends on the source image pixel format. The resulting image is if the source bitmap is not extended, and otherwise.

member.name: N:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms
member.summary: The namespace provides access to Graphics Mill transforms and attendant functionality. Most classes of this namespace represent single transform algorithm.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AddNoise
member.summary: Applies a noise effect to an image.

remarks.para: This class transforms an image by adding a random number to each pixel. It supports the following settings:

item.description: specifies a noise distribution (uniform or Gaussian).
specifies a strength of the noise.
specifies whether to put the same noise values to all channels of pixel.
specifies the seed for random generator.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AddNoise.Amount
member.summary: Gets or sets an amount (strength) of the noise.
member.value: The strength of noise in range [-1, 1]. If 0, no noise added. The default value is 0.2.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AddNoise.DistributionKind
member.summary: Gets or sets a distribution kind of the noise.
member.value: A specifying noise distribution law. The default value is .

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AddNoise.GrayNoise
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the noise is gray.
member.value: true if the noise is gray; otherwise, false. The default value is false.
member.remarks: If this property is true, the generated random value is the same for all channels of one pixel; otherwise the noise is color and the random value may vary for each channel in one pixel.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AddNoise.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

overloads.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AddNoise.#ctor(System.Single)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified noise strength.
member.param: The strength of noise in range [-1, 1]. You can change this value later through the property.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AddNoise.#ctor(System.Single,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.DistributionKind)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified noise type and strength.
member.param: The strength of noise in range [-1, 1]. You can change this value later through the property.
A specifying noise distribution law. You can change this value later through the property.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AddNoise.#ctor(System.Single,Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.DistributionKind,System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified noise settings.
member.param: The strength of noise in range [-1, 1]. You can change this value later through the property.
A specifying noise distribution law. You can change this value later through the property.
true if the noise is gray; otherwise, false. You can change this value later through the property.
The seed for the noise random generator. You can change this value later through the property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AddNoise.Seed
member.summary: Gets or sets a seed value for the noise random generator.
member.value: The seed for the noise random generator. The default value is 0.

remarks.para: The set of random numbers is always the same for the same seed. So if you need to have the same result for multiple execution of this transform, specify a fixed seed. If you want to have different result each time you run this transform, set this property randomly (for example, from system clock or some other unpredictable value).

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AdjustHsl
member.summary: Adjusts an image in HSL color space.

remarks.para: This transform supports the , , and settings. The specified values are added to appropriate components in HSL color space to each pixel.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AdjustHsl.Hue
member.summary: Gets or sets a hue modifier.
member.value: The hue modifier value in range [-1, 1] (degrees normalized at 360). The default value is 0.
member.remarks: Hue is measured in degrees relatively red point on color wheel. It means that if, for example, you specify 120 degrees, red color will turn to green, etc.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AdjustHsl.Lightness
member.summary: Gets or sets a lightness modifier.
member.value: The lightness modifier value in range [-1, 1]. The default value is 0.
member.remarks: This parameter allows to change intensity of the color. It works similar to transform, however another algorithm is used and result differs from brightness adjustment.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AdjustHsl.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

overloads.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AdjustHsl.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified noise settings.
member.param: The hue modifier value in range [-1, 1]. You can change this value later through the property.
The saturation modifier value in range [-1, 1]. You can change this value later through the property.
The lightness modifier value in range [-1, 1]. You can change this value later through the property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AdjustHsl.Saturation
member.summary: Gets or sets a saturation modifier.
member.value: The saturation modifier value in range [-1, 1]. The default value is 0.
member.remarks: Saturation means "purity" of the color. Small (negative) values will make image desaturated, gray. Large values will make image very saturated, all the color will be deep. Note, natural colors are seldom very saturated, so if you apply this method on photo, don't make this parameter close to maximum (if you don't deal with tropical butterflies and flowers).

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.AutoCrop
member.summary: Removes a border around an image in the automatic mode.

remarks.para: This transform supports two settings:

item.description: The color of the border to remove.
The sensitivity of the auto crop. The higher the value the more color will be cropped.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

The default background color is white, you can change it via the property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BezierTransform.SourceCellSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the cells to which the image will be splitted to perform transformation.
member.value: The size of the cells to which the image will be splitted to perform transformation.

remarks.para: The smaller number gives better result, but slows transformation. The grater number gives faster transformation, but can result in not so smooth image.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode
member.summary: Contains standard blend modes. They are used when the bitmap is drawn on window or blended with another bitmap.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.ColorBurn
member.summary: Divides the inverted bottom layer by the top layer, and then inverts the result.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.ColorDodge
member.summary: Divides the bottom layer by the inverted top layer.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.Darken
member.summary: Creates a pixel that retains the smallest components of the foreground and background pixels.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.Difference
member.summary: Subtracts the bottom layer from the top layer or vice versa to get a positive value.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.Exclusion
member.summary: Subtracts the bottom layer from the top layer or vice versa to get a positive value. It's less contrast than .

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.HardLight
member.summary: Combines and blend modes.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.Lighten
member.summary: Selects the maximum of each component from the foreground and background pixels.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.Multiply
member.summary: Multiplies pixels of the top layer with the corresponding pixels of the bottom layer.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.Normal
member.summary: Uses the top layer alone.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.Overlay
member.summary: Combines and blend modes.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.Screen
member.summary: The pixels in the two layers are inverted, multiplied, and then inverted again.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.BlendMode.SoftLight
member.summary: Combines and blend modes.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Blur.Radius
member.summary: Gets or sets the blur radius.
member.value: The blur radius must be positive. The default value is 2.

remarks.para: Radius means how much neighbour pixels the algorithm fetches (for radius = 1 it will take 8 neighbours, for radius = 2 it will use already 24 neighbour pixels, etc). That's why in general the larger radius, the slower blur works. However Graphics Mill implements special algorithms which are optimized for large radiuses, that's why this rule not always works.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Brightness
member.summary: Corrects a brightness of an image.

remarks.para: This class provides a simple brightness adjustment functionality. Being extremely easy-to-use for end user (it has the single parameter ), it is used by professional retouchers very seldom (because as usual it leads to losses of details in highlights and/or shadows).
You can also use this transform in automatic mode using property.

If you want to apply both brightness and contrast, you should consider the transform. Both of these operation will be performed at the single pass, so it will work faster than sequential execution of and .

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ChannelBalance
member.summary: Adjusts the channel balance of an image.

remarks.para: In order to modify the channel balance, specify an array of addends () and/or an array of multipliers ().

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ChannelBalance.Addends
member.summary: Gets or sets an array of addends.
member.value: The array of integer values in range [-max, max] which will be added to appropriate channels of all pixels. max is 255 (for non-extended pixel formats) or 65535 (for extended pixel formats).

remarks.note: If the length of this array is less than the number of channels in the target image, the rest channels will be unchanged. If there are more array entries than channels in the target image, all extra entries will be ignored.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ChannelBalance.MaxChannelCount
member.summary: Gets a maximum number of channels.
member.value: The maximum number of channels. Always 5.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ChannelBalance.Multipliers
member.summary: Gets or sets an array of multipliers.
member.value: The array of float values in range [-1, 1] which will be multiplied with appropriate channels of all pixels. These values are normalized to 255 (for non-extended pixel formats) or 65535 (for extended pixel formats).

remarks.note: If the length of this array is less than the number of channels in the target image, the rest channels will be unchanged. If there are more array entries than channels in the target image, all extra entries will be ignored.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ColorConverter
member.summary: Applies color conversion to an image.

remarks.para: This class should be used for appling color management during color conversions, drawing, and other operations where it is applicable. To choose the color management engine, use the property. You can specify such color management parameters as a default input profile (), output profile ( property), and profile for target device ( property). A color management intent parameter is accessible through the property.

After you set color management up, you can apply color conversions. This class applies two different kinds of color conversion: conversion to indexed pixel formats (color reduction) and conversion to continuous ones.

member.value: The background color. The default value is white color.
member.remarks: This property makes sense only when you convert from pixel format which supports alpha channel to pixel format which does not.

member.summary: Gets or sets color management engine which will be used during image transformation. Graphics Mill supports the following engines: LittleCMS and Adobe CMM. The property also allows disabling color management and perform transformation without color matching.
member.value: A to use.

remarks.para: Color management will be applied during transformation of image between color formats in case if all the following conditions are met:

item.description: This property is set to or .

The which needs to be transformed has a initialized with a correct color profile (e.g. it is embedded color profile loaded from image file, or this property is initialized after the image has been loaded or created). Additionally you can use the to be sure that an input profile is set.
An output color profile is initialized via the property.

remarks.para: If you do not need to apply color management during image transformation, set this property to .

remarks.para: The destination color space is specified by the property. The color space of this pixel format is a destination color space.

If you want to apply color management during conversion of this color, use the overload of this method. This profile will be used as an input profile, output profile is specified by the property. The property will be used as well.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ColorConverter.TransparentIndexThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets a transparency threshold.
member.value: The threshold is range [0, 255]. The default value is 128.

remarks.para: When building a palette during color reduction for an image which should be saved to GIF, you need to have the only one transparent color. However during color reduction you may get a number of colors with a different level of transparency. To avoid this, use this property. All alpha channel values which are greater or equal to this value will be changed to 255 (fully opaque), otherwise it will be 0.

member.summary: Color management is disabled.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ColorQuantizationAlgorithm
member.summary: Contains possible values of color quantization algorithms.

remarks.para: Color quantization is a process that reduces the number of distinct colors used in an image with the intention that the new image should be as visually similar as possible to the original image. It is used when you convert, say, 24-bit image to 8-bit (or lower).

summary.para: Median cut algorithm. The algorithm fits a box around all colors used in the RGB colorspace which it splits at the median value of its longest side. The algorithm stops after 255 recursions. All colors in one box are mapped to the centroid of this box.
Implementing this algorithm on very big images can cause an exception in Graphics Mill x86 (32-bit) edition.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ColorQuantizationAlgorithm.Octree
member.summary: Octree algorithm. The algorithm encodes image colour data as an octree up to nine levels deep. The node index to branch out from at the top level is determined by a formula that uses the most significant bits of the red, green, and blue colour components. The next lower level uses the next bit significance, and so on. Less significant bits are sometimes ignored to reduce the tree size. The algorithm is highly memory efficient because the tree's size can be limited. The bottom level of the octree consists of leaf nodes that accrue colour data not represented in the tree; these nodes initially contain single bits. If much more than the desired number of palette colours are entered into the octree, its size can be continually reduced by seeking out a bottom-level node and averaging its bit data up into a leaf node, pruning part of the tree. Once sampling is complete, exploring all routes in the tree down to the leaf nodes, taking note of the bits along the way, will yield approximately the required number of colours.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ColorTransformationIntent
member.summary: Contains possible values for color management rendering intents.

remarks.para: The definition of the rendering intent is given in ICC Profile Format Specification Version 3.4 which can be downloaded at this site:

According to this document, rendering intent specifies the style of reproduction to be used during the evaluation of this profile in a sequence of profiles. It applies specifically to that profile in the sequence and not to the entire sequence. Typically, the user or application will set the rendering intent dynamically at runtime or embedding time.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ColorTransformationIntent.AbsoluteColorimetric
member.summary: Absolute colorimetric intent (also known as match intent). In this intent, any colors that fall outside the output device range are adjusted to the closest color that can be rendered, while all other colors are left unchanged. White point is preserved. For example, the whitest white of a paper is more yellow than the whitest white of a computer monitor. An image converted into the gamut of the printer using match intent would result in all colors being converted and matched into the gamut of the printer. The white point of the image is not moved to match the white point of the printer. Therefore, the distance of the colors to the white point may change. This produces an image that is less visually disconcerting to the user, but is also a less accurate rendition of printer output.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ColorTransformationIntent.Perceptual
member.summary: Perceptual intent (also known as picture intent). According to clause 4.9 of ICC specification perceptual intent is a rendering intent that specifies the full gamut of the image is compressed or expanded to fill the gamut of the destination device. Gray balance is preserved but colorimetric accuracy might not be preserved.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ColorTransformationIntent.RelativeColorimetric
member.summary: Relative colorimetric intent (also known as proof intent). In this intent, any colors that fall outside the output device range are adjusted to the closest color that can be rendered, while all other colors are left unchanged. However white point is not preserved. For example, the whitest white of a paper is more yellow than the whitest white of a computer monitor. An image converted into the gamut of the printer using relative colorimetric intent would result in all colors becoming more yellow. The white point of the image is moved to match the white point of the printer. All other colors in the image keep their position relative to the white point. This produces an image that more accurately reflects what the printed image will look like. However, the user may find it visually disconcerting.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ColorTransformationIntent.RelativeColorimetricBpc
member.summary: Relative colorimetric intent (also known as proof intent) with additional black point compensation. In addition to operations made with intent, this one tries to improve image histogram.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ColorTransformationIntent.Saturation
member.summary: Saturation intent (also known as graphics intent). According to clause 4.12 of ICC specification, saturation intent is a rendering intent that specifies the saturation of the pixels in the image is preserved perhaps at the expense of accuracy in hue and lightness.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode
member.summary: Contains possible combine modes. They are used when the bitmap is drawn on window or blended with another bitmap.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Add
member.summary: Add combine mode. It sums pixel values of the source and overlaying images taking into account their transparency.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Alpha
member.summary: Alpha combine mode. Each overlaying pixel is blended with the corresponding source pixel. The opacity value of the overlaying image is taken into account. Makes sense only if the overlaying image has alpha channel.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.AlphaOverlapped
member.summary: Alpha overlapped combine mode. The same as , but the resulting alpha channel is calculated as the maximum between the source and overlaying alpha channels. This mode is useful only when both, the source and the overlaying images have alpha channels.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.AlphaOverlay
member.summary: Alpha overlay combine mode. Allows blending multiple transparent images and supports image reordering without quality loss.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.And
member.summary: AND combine mode. Bitwise AND operation is applied to the source and overlaying colors.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Behind
member.summary: Behind combine mode. Colors are blended only in the semi-transparent areas of the overlaying image. The opaque areas are ignored.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Color
member.summary: Color combine mode. Hue and saturation of the resulting color are taken from the overlaying color, and the luminosity is taken from the overlaying color. This mode is useful for tinting images.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Copy
member.summary: Copy combine mode. Each overlaying pixel replaces the corresponding source pixel. The opacity value is ignored, as a result the transparent zones become black.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Difference
member.summary: Difference combine mode. The resulting value is the difference between the source and overlaying colors, whichever has the greater luminosity.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Divide
member.summary: Divide combine mode. The resulting value is source pixel divided by the overlaying one.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Hue
member.summary: Hue combine mode. The hue of the resulting color is taken from the overlaying color, and the other components, saturation and luminosity, are taken from the source color.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.IfDarker
member.summary: "If Darker" combine mode. The resulting color is defined as the darkest between the colors of source and overlaying images.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.IfLighter
member.summary: "If Lighter" combine mode. The resulting color is defined as the lightest between the colors of source and overlaying images.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Invert
member.summary: Invert combine mode. The overlaying image is inverted and blended with the source image in the same way as in the mode.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Luminosity
member.summary: Luminosity combine mode. The luminosity of the resulting color is taken from the overlaying color, and the other components are taken from the source color.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Multiply
member.summary: Multiply combine mode. The source color is multiplied by the overlaying one. The resulting value is normalized to the maximum luminosity value.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Or
member.summary: OR combine mode. Bitwise OR operation is applied to the source and overlaying colors.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Overlay
member.summary: Overlay combine mode. Depending on the source pixel luminosity the (lightening) or the (darkening) mode is used to calculate the resulting pixel. The lighter the source pixel, the lighter the resulting pixel; and the darker the source pixel, the darker the resulting pixel.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Saturation
member.summary: Saturation combine mode. The saturation of the resulting color is taken from the overlaying color, and the other components are taken from the source color.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Screen
member.summary: Screen combine mode. The overlaying color is inverted and multiplied by the source one. The resulting value is normalized to the maximum luminosity value.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Subtract
member.summary: Substract combine mode. The source and overlaying colors are added, and then the maximum luminosity value is subtracted from the resulting value.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Texturize
member.summary: Texturize combine mode. The overlaying image is converted to grayscale and blended with the source image in the same way as in the mode.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.CombineMode.Xor
member.summary: XOR combine mode. Bitwise XOR operation is applied to the source and overlaying colors.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Crop
member.summary: Crops an image.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize
member.summary: Applies a cylindrize transformation on an image.

remarks.para: This transformation is useful if you need to emulate the image to be bended on the cylinder surface, for example, mug. In this case the following sequence is used:

item.description: Use to fit the bitmap to cylinder parameters.
Use to distort the bitmap.
Combine distorted bitmap and mug image using class or method.

remarks.para: You can specify a number of cylinder parameters: height ( property), half-perimeter ( property), color ( property). You can also specify position of the image relatively top left corner of the "face" part of cylinder ( and properties). If the cylinder (e.g. mug) is tilted, you can take it into account with property. And of course like for any other geometry bitmap transform, you can specify interpolation algorithm ( property) and background color ( property).

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize.Apply(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap)
member.summary: Produces a cylindrized copy of a given bitmap. The source bitmap remains unchanged.
member.param: A to cylindrize.
member.returns: A new containing the result of cylindrize transformation.

member.summary: Gets or sets a background color. This color will be used to fill all the areas which are out of the cylinder.
member.value: The background color. The default value is transparent white.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize.CupColor
member.summary: Gets or sets a cylinder color. This color is used to fill the cylinder surface which is not covered with bitmap pixels.
member.value: The cylinder color. The default value is transparent white.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize.CylinderHalfPerimeter
member.summary: Gets or sets a half-perimeter of the cylinder (i.e. length of the surface visible to user).
member.value: A half-perimeter of the cylinder. The default value is -1.
member.remarks: If this property is -1, the width of the bitmap will be taken. If you want entire image to fit on the visible part of cylinder, you should resize the bitmap first to make its width equal to cylinder half-perimeter.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize.CylinderHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the cylinder height.
member.value: The height of the cylinder. The default value is -1.
member.remarks: If this property is -1, the height of the bitmap will be taken.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resources used by this .

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize.HorizontalOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets a horizontal offset of the bitmap relatively to the upper-left corner of the visible part of the cylinder.
member.value: The horizontal offset of the bitmap on the cylinder.
member.remarks: If the offset is negative, the image will be shifted left on cylinder and part of the image will be invisible. Positive offset will shift the image right. Empty space between the left edge of bitmap and edge of the visible part of cylinder will be filled with .

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize.InterpolationMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the interpolation mode of the transform (i.e. algorithm which is used to resample bitmap).
member.value: A specifying interpolation algorithm used in the transform.
member.remarks: As usual fast interpolation algorithms produces lower quality comparing to slow ones, and vice versa. That's why using this property you can select between speed and quality of cylindrizing.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize.SlopeAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets a slope angle of the cylinder.
member.value: A slope angle of the cylinder. The default value is 5.
member.remarks: It is often you need to bend the image on the cylindric surface like a mug, which is slightly tilted toward to user. It happens when objective of the camera shooting the mug is higher than mug. In this case you should estimate the angle of the slope and set it to this property to obtain more realistic result.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Cylindrize.VerticalOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets a vertical offset of the bitmap relatively to the upper-left corner of the visible part of the cylinder.
member.value: The vertical offset of the bitmap on the cylinder.
member.remarks: If the offset is negative, the image will be shifted up on cylinder and part of the image will be invisible. Positive offset will shift the image down. Empty space between the top edge of bitmap and edge of the visible part of cylinder will be filled with .

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.FloodFill
member.summary: Applies a flood fill transformation (analogue to Paint Bucket tool in the Adobe Photoshop) to an image.

remarks.para: This transform works in the following way: you specify a start point (with property) and it begins filling this point and its neighbour with a color specified with the property until a boundary will be met. Boundary can be defined in different ways: either as pixels of color equal to property, or pixels which differ from this color. It is specified with property.

As color values can differ very slightly (due various factors: noise, JPEG compression artifacts, or image features), sometimes algorithm can work not very well. In these situations you can use property . This property means the how close current pixel color can be to target color to match. If tolerance is very small only colors very close to target color matches. If big value specified (near 1), almost all colors matches. Thereby if property is set to false, algorithm will just replace all matching colors, otherwise it will blend matching colors with the original pixel using distance between these colors as a transparency level (this way you can produce more or less smooth edges on the boundaries).

member.value: A value specifying how to determine the filling area boundary. The default value is .

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to leave alpha channel intacted with the flood fill algorithm.
member.value: true if to preserve alpha channel; otherwise, false. The default value is true.
member.remarks: If true, alpha channel will not be overwritten by the .

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.FloodFill.ProcessHalftones
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to fill colors which are not exactly match the .
member.value: true if tolerant colors are alpha-blended; otherwise, false. The default value is true.
member.remarks: This property specifies how to handle situations when the current color does not exactly match target color, but tolerant to it (with specified the property). If false, this pixel is replaced with , if true, it is alpha-blended (alpha is calculated as 1 - T, where T is actual tolerance between these colors).

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.FloodFill.TargetColor
member.summary: Gets or sets a target color that is used to find the boundaries of area to fill.
member.value: A used to determine the filling area boundaries. The default value is a white color.
member.remarks: If is , this property specifies a border color (when algorithm meets this color, it stops filling). If is , this property specifies a surface color (algorithm continue filling till current color is the same as target color).

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.FloodFill.Tolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets a maximum allowed tolerance for the target color.
member.value: The tolerance for the target color in range [0, 1]. The default value is 0.1.
member.remarks: This property specifies an admissible tolerance (distance between colors in color space) when comparing current color and target color (see comments for targetColor). Minimum value (0) means exact match of the colors, maximum value (1) means that any color matches.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.HistogramEqualize
member.summary: Applies a histogram equalization.
Applies a histogram equalization.

remarks.para: Histogram equalization algorithm is used for automatically enhancing the image contrast. As usual it makes the image too posterized, that's why it is seldom used to with photos (you should use effect with property set to true). However it suits for scientific tasks (as a preparation before applying some specific algorithm like vectorization, recognition, etc).

The main idea of this algorithm is to build a look-up table (LUT) which makes the bitmap histogram equalized (all histogram entries are equal each other). Actually the histogram is never equalized absolutely, however this algorithm makes it as much as possible. After that this LUT is applied using class.

This class enables you to use not only histogram of the source bitmap, but any other histogram too. In this case algorithm will build the LUT for this histogram, but apply this LUT on the source bitmap. To specify another histogram, use property . If you want to get a histogram from the bitmap automatically, set null to this property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.HistogramEqualize.Histogram
member.summary: Gets or sets a histogram to be equalized.
member.value: A to equalize. The default value is null.
member.remarks: If histogram is not set (this property is null), algorithm automatically builds it from the bitmap at which the effect is applied (depending on property). Otherwise it will build LUT that equalizes this histogram and apply it on the image.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.HistogramEqualize.HistogramMode
member.summary: Gets or sets value that specifies how to build histogram if no custom histogram specified.
member.value: A specifying how to build histogram if no custom histogram specified.
member.remarks: If both and specified, histogram mode is ignored (custom histogram used).

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Levels
member.summary: Applies levels correction to an image.

remarks.para: Using this class you can apply a tone correction similar to Adobe Photoshop Levels effect. You specify , and , as well as and modifiers. These values work in the same way as appropriate sliders in Adobe Photoshop.
It also can be applied automatically. To do it, set property to true.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Levels.Auto
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the transform should be run in automatic mode.
member.value: true if the levels correction is automatic; otherwise, false.

remarks.note: If you set property to true, and modifying other settings, is reset to false.
remarks.para: When you create without settings, default value is true. If the settings are passed to constructor, default value is false.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Levels.Highlights
member.summary: Gets or sets a highlights level modifier.
member.value: The highlights level modifier in range [0, 1].

remarks.para: This value is normalized to 1. Inside the transform it will be stretched to 255 or 65355 depending on pixel format (for 8 bits per channel formats it will be 255, for 16 bit per channel - 65355). For example, if you apply this transform on the bitmap with pixel format, and this property is 0.9, algorithm will treat it as 229.
With this property you specify the upper bound of new tone range.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Levels.HistogramMode
member.summary: Gets or sets value that specifies how to build histogram during levels adjusting.
member.value: A value that specifies how to build histogram during levels adjusting.
member.remarks: Adobe Photoshop builds histogram using technique.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Levels.MaximumLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets a maximum output level.
member.value: The maximum output level in range [0, 1].

remarks.para: This value is normalized to 1. Inside the transform it will be stretched to 255 or 65355 depending on pixel format (for 8 bits per channel formats it will be 255, for 16 bit per channel - 65355). For example, for example, if you apply this transform on the bitmap with pixel format, and this property is 0.9, algorithm will treat it as 229.

This property is useful when you are preparing an image for printing at the printer which does not support too high tone levels. This way instead of truncating highlights you can compress a tone range and preserve details in highlights at the hardcopy.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Levels.Midtones

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Levels.MinimumLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets a minimum output level.
member.value: The minimum output level in range [0, 1].

remarks.para: This value is normalized to 1. Inside the transform it will be stretched to 255 or 65355 depending on pixel format (for 8 bits per channel formats it will be 255, for 16 bit per channel - 65355). For example, for example, if you apply this transform on the bitmap with pixel format, and this property is 0.1, algorithm will treat it as 25.

This property is useful when you are preparing image for printing at the printer which does not support too low tone levels. This way instead of truncating shadows you can compress a tone range and preserve details in shadows at the hardcopy.

item.description: If you want to get a result similar to Photoshop 7, use 0.5% (0.005).
If you want a result similar to Photoshop CS or later, use 0.1% (0.001).

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Lut
member.summary: Represents a look-up table (LUT) used for intensity transformation.

remarks.para: Look-up tables are used in most tone correction algorithms. LUT defines a "luminosity function", in other words, a rule which translate channel luminosity to another value. This class defines this function as an array of points and interpolation algorithm.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.MaskTransform
member.summary: Represents a base class for all transforms which can be applied with mask.

remarks.para: All the transforms inherited from this class do not modify neither pixel format of the bitmap, nor its dimensions. It means that these transforms can be applied directly in-place (without creating bitmap copy).

Another interesting feature of this class descendants is the ability to apply the effect with specified mask. Mask is a grayscale image of the same size as a target bitmap which defines "region of interest" (ROI) in raster form. Black pixels on this mask are treated as transparent and effect is applied for appropriate pixels on target bitmap. White pixels are opaque and original pixels are copied to the target bitmap. Mask can be compared with a following sequense of actions:

item.description: Effect is applied on copy of the original image.
Mask bitmap replaces alpha channel in modified image.
This image is alpha-blended with original image.

remarks.para: To apply transform with mask, you should use method.

member.summary: Transforms given bitmap using specified mask.
member.param: A to transfrom.
A containing a mask for transformation.
member.returns: A bitmap containing the result of the transformation.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Matrix
member.summary: Encapsulates a 3-by-3 affine matrix that represents a geometric transform.

remarks.para: The 3x3 matrix is used to apply geometry transformation on a bitmap. Geometry transformation can be both affine (such as scale, skew or rotate) and projective (such as perspective correction).

You can create this class instance in two ways: create a new matrix and then manually fill it using property, or generate it from points representing affine or projective transformation (see and methods for more details).

This class also implements some matrix algebraic operations, such as matrix inversion, multiplication, determinant calculation, and etc. Moreover you can apply affine operations at the matrix: rotate ( and methods), scale ( method), and translate ( method).

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Matrix.IsIdentity
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this is the identity matrix.
member.value: true if this is identity; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: Identifty matrix is a matrix which has a following structure: all elements of the main diagonal (i.e. A[0,0], A[1,1], and A[2,2]) are equal to 1, all other elements are equal to 0.

This kind of matrix is very important in the linear algebra. It has the following characteristics: when you multiply any other matrix or a vector by an identify matrix, the result is the same as an input matrix or vector. In other words, it represents a neutral element for an operation of matrix multiplication.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Matrix.IsInvertible
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this is invertible.
member.value: true if this is invertible; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: The matrix cannot be inverted when it is singular, i.e. its determinant is 0. Therefore you can just check the property instead of this one.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Matrix.ToGdiPlusMatrix
member.summary: Returns a matrix converted to System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix.
member.returns: System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix class instance.

remarks.para: System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix is intended only for affine transforms, and it has only 6 elements (2 columns x 3 rows). Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Matrix supports also projective transforms, and has 9 elements (3 columns x 3 rows). When conversion is applied, the last column is discarded (since it is not supported by GDI+ matrix). So if you are converting matrix of the projective transform, you will get another result with GDI+ matrix.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.MatrixTransform
member.summary: Applies an arbitrary convex linear transformation to an image (such as perspective distortion, rotation, skew, etc).

remarks.para: To apply a transfomation (both affine and projective), you should create a matrix of the linear transformation (see class for more details). The only limitation - the matrix should not be singular (i.e. transformation must be convex). Put this matrix to the property.

In fact, such transforms as and are special cases of the linear transformations. You can emulate these transforms by providing scaling/rotating matrix to this transform. However and are optimized and we recommend to use it when you need only to resize or rotate.
As for all other geometry transforms you can specify the (which affects on the algorithm speed and output quality) and .

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Maximum
member.summary: Applies a maximum filter (also known as erosion) to an image.

remarks.para: Maximum filter is a non-linear filter which works in the following way: for each pixel it searches pixel with maximum brightness in "running window" of the radius specified with property. This pixel is copied to the result bitmap.
That's why if you apply this filter on the image with has black objects on white background (for example text), they will be erosed.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified filter radius.
member.param: The radius of the filter in pixels. You can change it later using the property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Maximum.Radius
member.summary: Gets or sets a radius of maximum filter.
member.value: The radius of the filter in pixels.
member.remarks: This property specifies how much neighbour pixels will be processed (for radius = 1 it will take 8 neighbours, for radius = 2 it will use already 24 neighbour pixels, etc). That's why the larger radius you specify, the slower algorithm will work. It is recommended to limit user input for this parameter to avoid performance drop.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Median
member.summary: Applies a median filter to an image.

remarks.para: Median filter is a non-linear filter which works in the following way: for each pixel it searches median pixel in "running window" of the radius specified with property. This pixel is copied to the result bitmap.
This filter is good for removing noise (especially impulse noise).

member.remarks: This property specifies how much neighbour pixels will be processed (for radius = 1 it will take 8 neighbours, for radius = 2 it will use already 24 neighbour pixels, etc). That's why the larger radius you specify, the slower algorithm will work. It is recommended to limit user input for this parameter to avoid performance drop.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Minimum
member.summary: Applies a minimum filter (also known as dilation) to an image.

remarks.para: Minimum filter is a non-linear filter which works in the following way: for each pixel it searches pixel with minimum brightness in "running window" of the radius specified with property. This pixel is copied to the result bitmap.
That's why if you apply this filter on the image with has black objects on white background (for example text), they will be dilated.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeBlob
member.summary: Represents a red eye blob (i.e. an area which corresponds to a red eye).

remarks.para: This class is accessible via the RedEyeMask.Blobs property. The blob is described by two parameters: point and box. All values are given in coordinates of the red eye mask this blob object is returned from.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeBlob.BoundingRectangle
member.summary: Gets a bounding rectangle of this red eye blob.
member.value: A structure that specifies a bounding box of this red eye blob.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeBlob.Center
member.summary: Gets a center of this red eye blob.
member.value: A structure that specifies a center of this red eye blob.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeMask
member.summary: Represents a red eye mask calculated during the red eye removal process.

remarks.para: When the transform is working, it builds a mask which contains the information about red eyes found in the image. You can get this mask through the property. Of course, you can do it only after the algorithm completes.
This mask is a common grayscale bitmap where white areas correspond to red eyes and black ones - all the rest. You can get this bitmap using the property.
You can get blobs of the mask using the property which returns an array of objects.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeMask.BinaryMask
member.summary: Gets a grayscale bitmap which represents the red eye mask.
member.value: A which represents a red eye mask.

remarks.para: A pixel format of this bitmap is always . White areas correspond to portions of the source image which are recognized as red eyes (i.e. red eye blobs). If you need to get coordinates of the red eye blobs, use the property. It will return an array of objects.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeMask.Blobs
member.summary: Gets an array of red eye blobs found in the image (i.e. areas which correspond to red eyes).
member.value: An array of objects.

remarks.para: Use this property to determine where the algorithm has found red eyes. For example, you can display to the user what portions of image are about to be modified. If the algorithm finds it incorrectly, the user can fix blobs coordinates and proceed with mode.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeMask.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resources used by this .

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeMask.Height
member.summary: Gets a height of the red eye mask.
member.value: The height of the mask. Its dimensions are always the same as the face selection rectangle.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeMask.Mask
member.summary: Gets a two-dimensional array of values which represents a mask.
member.value: Two-dimensional array of values which represents a mask.

remarks.para: To get the mask as a bitmap, use the property instead.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeMask.Width
member.summary: Gets a width of the red eye mask.
member.value: The width of the mask. Its dimensions are always the same as the face selection rectangle.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeRemoval
member.summary: Removes a red eye effect from an image.

remarks.para: Using this class you can add red eye removal functionality into your application. It supports two modes: and .
In the mode, the tranfrom works in two steps:

item.description: Select the face of the person whose eyes should be processed. The selection should be specified by the property.
Specify red eye coordinates on the selected face (e.g. by mouse click). It is specified by the property.

remarks.para: The mode also requires the user to select a face. However it automatically searches red eyes on the selected face. When this mode is used, you can get the coordinates of red eyes found by the algorithm with a help of the property. This way if the algorithm mistakes, you can display the user what was found and possible give them an opportunity to fix it manually. See the and classes description for more details on this.
If you are not happy with results, you can play with sensitivity of the algorithm. Try to reduce the property slightly. In the mode you can play with additional property, namely .
remarks.note: Both modes analyzes facial features when deciding what red pixels should be suppressed and what ones should not. This way the algorithm reduces probability of malfunction (i.e. mistake reddish areas of the face or background for red eyes). The more precise the user selects the face, the more accurate red eye effect removal will be. Also, if the user works in the mode, they need try to click inside the red area of an eye. If the user clicks, say, white area of the flash reflection, the algorithm will not be able to fix red eye effect.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeRemoval.Apply(Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Bitmap)
member.summary: Produces a transformed copy of a given bitmap. The source bitmap remains unchanged.
member.param: An to transform.
member.returns: A new containing the result of red eye removal transformation.

member.name: M:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeRemoval.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resources used by this .

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeRemoval.EyePoint
member.summary: Gets or sets the point inside the eye.
member.value: A containing the red eye location. Coordinates should be specified relatively to the upper-left corner of the .

remarks.para: This property makes sense only when the property is . Typically the user clicks the red eye position with a mouse button. You should recalculate these coordinates relatively the face selection (specified by the property).
remarks.note: If you specify the point outside of the rectangle the transform fails.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeRemoval.FaceRegion
member.summary: Gets or sets the rectangle which selects the person's face.
member.value: A structure containing the face region.

remarks.para: When the algorithm works, it analyzes facial features. It helps to reduce probability of malfunction. To make the transformation process as precise as possible, you should have the user to select the person's face as accurate as possible.
Users should select the face even if they use mode. The eye they select should be inside this rectangle.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeRemoval.Mask
member.summary: Gets the mask built during the red eye removal process.
member.value: A generated during the red eye removal process.

remarks.para: You can use this property when you apply the red eye effect removal in mode to determine what image elements were recognized as red eyes. To do it, use the property of the class. If you need to get this mask as a bitmap, use the property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeRemoval.Mode
member.summary: Gets or sets the red eye removal mode (manual or automatic).
member.value: A value which specify the mode of the red eye removal algorithm.

remarks.para: When you use mode, the user should click eyes manually. When mode is used, eyes are searched automatically. However in both cases the user should select the face which contains red eyes.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeRemoval.RedChannelThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets the red channel threshold used during the red eye removal process.
member.value: A float number in range [0, 1] which specifies the red channel threshold.

remarks.para: If the thershold is close to 0, the algorithm captures a lot of pixels (even those which are unlikely to be red). It highly reduces the performance and increase a number of false recognitions. Too high values may lead to reducing of probability of red eye removal. It is highly recommended to use default value of this property and adjust it only if it is actually necessary.
This property affects both for and modes.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RedEyeRemoval.Sensitivity
member.summary: Gets or sets a sensitivity of the algorithm in mode.
member.value: A float number in range [0, 1] which specifies a sensitivity of the red eye removal algorithm. The smaller value you specify, more pixels are affected.

remarks.para: This value is ignored in mode (unlike property value).
It is recommended to use the default value of this property. However if you are not happy with the result, you can try to adjust it.

The more precise the user selects the face, the more accurate red eye effect removal will be.

member.summary: Manual mode. The user selects a face and clicks red eyes inside it. It makes sense to warn the user to click inside the red area of an eye. If the user clicks, say, white area of the flash reflection, the algorithm will not be able to fix a red eye effect.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.RemoveAlpha

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Resize
member.summary: Resizes an image.

remarks.para: Using this class you may resample the bitmap: specify and properties, then apply the transform, and it will return resized bitmap. If you set some of these properties to 0, this property is automatically calculated to preserve the aspect ratio of the image.

Essential parameter of all the geometric transforms (including resizing) is an interpolation algorithm. It specifies how to calculate intermediate points. Different algorithms produces different quality, but as usual the higher quality it produces, the slower algorithm works. You can select interpolation algorithm with property.

example.para: The following code proportionally resizes an image to 100 pixel width.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ResizeMode
member.summary: Contains values for the resize modes (how the resize parameters should be intepreted).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ResizeMode.Fit
member.summary: Width and height specify a rectangle the image is inscribed into (image proportions are preserved).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ResizeMode.ImageFill
member.summary: In this mode image is proportionally resized and cropped. Firstly, the image is resized so that the given rectangle is inscribed into the resized image. After that the rectangle is centered on the resized image and the image is cropped by the rectangle bounds.

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ResizeMode.Resize
member.summary: Width and height specify dimensions of the image after resize (proportions are not preserved).

member.name: F:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.ResizeMode.Shrink
member.summary: The same as Fit, but the resize occurs only if resize dimensions are smaller than image dimensions.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Rotate
member.summary: Rotates an image at arbitrary angle.

remarks.para: The main parameter of this transform is to rotate the image to. If specified angle is 90, 180, or 270 degrees, a special algorithm which avoids floating-point calculations is used automatically, which yields to higher performance.
Another important property is that defines an interpolation algorithm. Different algorithms produce different quality, but as usual the higher quality an algorithm produces, the slower it works.

example.para: The following code rotates an image by 5 degrees clockwise.

member.summary: Gets or sets an angle to rotate the image at.
member.value: The angle to rotate the image at (in degrees). The default value is 0.
member.remarks: If specified angle is 90, 180, or 270 degrees, a special algorithm which avoids floating-point calculations is used automatically, which yields to higher performance.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Shadow
member.summary: Applies a shadow effect to an image.

remarks.para: When you apply this effect, the image drops a shadow with specified parameters (taking into account transparent areas of the image). This effect is ideal for creating artistic texts, logos, etc.

You can specify a number of shadow parameters. and specify offset of the shadow relatively the image. means the shadow color. To make shadow looking more realistic, it is blurred. You can set blur (amount of the shadow fuzziness). Property can be used to specify if the transform should increase size of the image to fit the shadow or it should truncate the shadow which is out of the original image (makes sense to set it to true when you create artistic thumbnails).
remarks.note: If the bitmap does not have an alpha channel (e.g. its pixel format is ), alpha channel is automatically added. So be aware that pixel format of the output bitmap may differ from the input one.

example.para: The following code gets the thumbnail from an image EXIF metadata, applies the transform on it, and saves the result:

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.SmartBlur.Radius
member.summary: Gets or sets the blur radius.
member.value: The smart blur radius must be positive.

remarks.para: Radius means how much neighbour pixels the algorithm fetches (for radius = 1 it will take 8 neighbours, for radius = 2 it will use already 24 neighbour pixels, etc). That's why in general the larger radius, the slower blur works. However Graphics Mill implements special algorithms which are optimized for large radiuses, that's why this rule not always works.

member.summary: Gets or sets the smart blur threshold.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Transparentize
member.summary: Applies a transparentize effect to an image.
member.remarks: This transform sets alpha values of pixels with a given color (and tolerant ones) to transparent. This transform is very useful when you need to blend two images and "upper" image does not have alpha channel, but it has a background color. For example, you draw a logo placed in the center of the image on white background. In this case you set to white color. You can also adjust a parameter to make colors close to white color semi-transparent (to get smooth colors). Besides of that is useful when background color is not completely uniform (for example, you loaded JPEG file with low quality).

member.summary: Gets or sets a color to transparentize.
member.value: A to transparentize. The default value is white.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.Transparentize.Threshold
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies admissible threshold (distance between colors in color space) when comparing current color and transparent color.
member.value: The threshold in range [0, 1].
member.remarks: Minimum value (0) means exact match of the colors, maximum value (1) means that any color matches.

member.name: T:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.UnsharpMask
member.summary: Increases a sharpness of an image by using the unsharp mask technique.

remarks.para: Unsharp mask is a wide-spread technique used by photographers to increase image sharpness even in precomputer times. The idea is to combine the image with the unfocused (blurred) version. This class provides the property to tune the blur effect. During combining the algorithm calculates the difference between corresponding pixels of original and blurred image. If this difference is greater than value specified with property, algorithm adds this N percents of this difference to original pixel (N is set by property). Otherwise no changes to original pixel is done. As blurred image differs from original ones mainly on the object edges, sharpening effect is achieved.

Using this technique is quite difficult to untrained user as it requires three non-intuitive parameters (amount, radius, and threshold). That's why if you want to provide user easy way to manipulate image sharpness, you can use transform which is less flexible, but much more easy-to-use.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.UnsharpMask.Amount
member.summary: Gets or sets unsharp mask amount (the difference between blurred and original image).
member.value: The unsharp mask amount. The default value is 1.
member.remarks: Amount*100 means the percentage of the difference between blurred and original image. Min value is 0.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified settings.
member.param: The unsharp mask amount. You can change it later using the property.
The blur radius used to produce unfocused version of the image. You can change it later using the property.
The threshold value for the unsharp mask in range [0, 1]. You can change it later using the property.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.UnsharpMask.Radius
member.summary: Gets or sets a blur radius used to produce unfocused version of the image (necessary for unsharp mask algorithm).
member.value: The blur radius used to produce unfocused version of the image. The default value is 1.

member.name: P:Aurigma.GraphicsMill.Transforms.UnsharpMask.Threshold
member.summary: Gets or sets a threshold value for the unsharp mask.
member.value: The threshold value for the unsharp mask in range [0, 1]. The default value is 0.1.
member.remarks: Minimum value (0) means that all pixels are affected with unsharp mask, maximum value means that no pixels are affected. To calculate threshold in pixel luminosity levels, multiply it on 255 for non-extended (8 bit per channel) images, or 65535 for extended (16 bit per channel) images.
